English: In the Indian language: Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra
In Tibetan: Engaging in the Conduct of a Bodhisattva
I prostrate to all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

I respectfully bow to the Dharmakaya of the Sugatas and their spiritual heirs,
And to all who are worthy of veneration.

Entering into the vows of the Sons of the Sugatas,
I will briefly explain according to scripture.
Nothing that has not occurred before is spoken of here.

I do not possess the skill of poetic composition.
Therefore, I have no thought of benefiting others.
I composed this for the purpose of meditating in my own mind.

In order to cultivate virtue, may my power of faith
Be increased for now by these [teachings].
And if others of equal fortune to myself
Should see these, may they find meaning and purpose.
This human life of leisure and opportunity is extremely difficult to obtain.

If one does not accomplish what is beneficial in this life,
How will one achieve genuine prosperity in the future?
For accomplishing the purpose of beings,
One must attain what is truly meaningful.

Just as on a dark, cloudy night,
A flash of lightning briefly illuminates all,
Likewise, by the power of the Buddha,
Worldly merit and wisdom occasionally arise for a moment.

tags:


Therefore, virtue is always weak and feeble,
While evil is powerful and utterly unbearable.
Except for the perfect mind of enlightenment,
What other virtue could overcome it?

The Mighty Sages, who have contemplated deeply for many eons,
Have seen that this very [teaching/practice] is beneficial.

Through this, countless multitudes of beings
Easily attain supreme bliss.

Wishing to destroy the hundreds of sufferings of existence,
Desiring to remove the unhappiness of sentient beings,
And longing to experience hundreds of joys,
Never abandon bodhicitta (the awakening mind).

tags:


When bodhicitta arises, in an instant,
Those wretched beings bound in samsara's prison
Are called children of the Sugatas,
And become worthy of homage by gods and humans of the world.

tags:


Like the supreme form of the alchemical elixir,
Taking this impure body and transforming it into the Buddha's form,
Transmuting it into a priceless jewel,
Hold firmly to what is called the mind of enlightenment.

When thoroughly examined by the immeasurable intellect,
The sole guide of beings is found to be precious.

Those who wish to be free from the realms of beings,
Hold firmly to the precious bodhicitta.

All other virtuous deeds are like water trees;
After bearing fruit, they are exhausted and come to an end.

The tree of bodhicitta (the awakened mind) is ever-growing,
Constantly bearing fruit, it increases inexhaustibly.

Even if one has committed utterly unbearable misdeeds,
By relying on the brave, as in great fear,
One who swiftly liberates by relying on that,
Why would the conscientious not rely on this?

Like the fire at the end of time,
It surely burns away great sins
In a single instant.

The immeasurable benefits of that
Were explained by the loving protector Norbulingka, endowed with wisdom.

In brief, the mind of enlightenment
Should be understood as having two aspects.

The aspiring mind of enlightenment
And the engaging mind of enlightenment itself.

Just as one understands the difference
Between wanting to go and actually going,
In the same way, the wise should understand
The distinction between these two in sequence.

From the mind that aspires to enlightenment,
Great fruits arise while in samsara.
However, unlike the mind of actual engagement,
It does not produce a continuous stream of merit.

From the moment one genuinely generates the irreversible mind
To liberate the infinite realms of sentient beings,
Even while sleeping or being heedless from that time onward,
A force of merit, unceasing and manifold,
Arises constantly, equal to space itself.

This was requested with reasoning
By Subāhu (Good Arm) through inquiry.
For the benefit of beings of lesser inclination,
The Tathagata himself spoke thus.

Even if one merely thinks of removing
The mental afflictions of sentient beings,
Such a beneficent intention
Is endowed with immeasurable merit.

What need is there to mention then
The wish to remove the countless sufferings
Of each and every sentient being,
And to establish each in boundless good qualities?
Whether father or mother, who has such benevolent thoughts as these?

Even among gods and sages,
Does this exist even for Brahma?

These sentient beings themselves,
Even in dreams have never before
Conceived such a thought for their own sake.
How then could it arise for the sake of others?

Others do not even arise for their own sake,
Yet this one thinks of the welfare of beings.
This special jewel of the mind,
An unprecedented marvel has arisen.

The cause of joy for all beings,
The elixir for the suffering of sentient creatures,
The merit of the precious mind -
How can it ever be measured?

Even by merely thinking of benefiting others,
One surpasses the merit of worshipping Buddhas.
What need is there to mention
Striving for the welfare and happiness of all sentient beings without exception?

Although one wishes to abandon suffering,
One rushes headlong into suffering itself.

Though desiring happiness, due to ignorance,
One destroys one's own happiness as if it were an enemy.

For those who lack happiness
And are filled with much suffering,
May they be satisfied with all joys
And be freed from all sufferings.
May their ignorance also be dispelled.
What virtue could equal this?
Where can such a friend be found?
How could there be such merit?

Those who repay kindness are worthy of praise for a time,
But what need is there to speak of bodhisattvas,
Who do good without being asked?

Even those who prepare a small amount of ordinary food,
Those who give just a moment's worth of food,
And those who feed others to fullness for half a day, albeit with contempt,
Are honored by people as doers of virtue.

For countless sentient beings, over a long time,
The unsurpassed bliss of the Sugatas (Buddhas),
Fulfilling all wishes in their minds,
Is constantly given - what need is there to mention mere giving?

Whoever harbors ill will towards such a bodhisattva benefactor,
For as many moments as they generate malicious thoughts,
They will remain in hell for that many eons -
Thus spoke the Sage (Buddha).

However, if one purifies the mind with sincere devotion,
The fruits of that will increase even more abundantly.

Even with great urgency, the bodhisattvas
Do not commit negative actions; virtuous deeds naturally increase.

I bow down to the body of the one
In whom the supreme precious mind has arisen.

To that which brings happiness even when harmed,
To that source of bliss, I go for refuge.

tags:


From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas," this is the first chapter called "Explaining the Benefits of the Bodhicitta Mind."

In order to grasp that precious mind,
I make excellent offerings to:
The Thus-Gone Ones and the holy Dharma,
The stainless Triple Gem and the children of the Buddhas,
And the oceans of good qualities.

Whatever flowers and fruits there may be,
And whatever kinds of medicines exist,
Whatever precious things there are in the world,
And whatever pure and pleasing waters there are,

Precious mountains, and likewise,
Secluded and delightful forest spots,
Trees adorned with ornaments of flowers,
And trees with good fruit and bowing branches,

Fragrances and incenses in the worlds of gods and others,
Wish-fulfilling trees and precious trees,
Crops that grow without cultivation,
And other ornaments worthy of offering,

Lakes and ponds adorned with lotuses,
With swans of very melodious and pleasing calls,
The vast expanse of space extending to the limits of all realms,
All these things that cannot be grasped,

Having mentally taken hold of them, I excellently offer
To the supreme sage, the Buddha, and his sons.
May the holy recipients, those of great compassion,
Think of me with love.
Please accept these offerings of mine.
I am one with little merit, a great pauper.
I have no other wealth of offerings.

Therefore, O Protector who contemplates the welfare of others,
Please accept this through your own power for my sake.

I offer my entire body eternally
To the Victorious Ones and their heirs.
Supreme bodhisattvas, please accept me completely.
With reverence, I come to be your servant/follower.
Since I am completely embraced by you, I have no fear in existence.
Benefit sentient beings.

I will truly transcend past negative actions,
And henceforth commit no further misdeeds.

tags:


The bathing chamber is filled with sweet fragrance,
Crystal floors laid out, clear and sparkling.
Adorned with lovely pillars of blazing jewels,
And canopies shimmering with pearls' light.

There, for the Tathagatas and their spiritual heirs,
Many precious vases filled with scented water,
Delightful and well-prepared, with songs and
Various musical instruments, offer the sacred bath.

Their bodies are clothed in incomparable garments;
They wipe their pure bodies with supremely fragrant substances.

Then, to that one, offer excellent robes
Of beautifully transformed colors,
Supreme and very fragrant.

tags:


With various fine, soft, and delicate garments,
And hundreds of excellent ornaments of all kinds,
I adorn Samantabhadra, Manjushri,
Avalokiteshvara, and other noble ones.

tags:


With the finest fragrances that spread their scent
Throughout the three thousand worlds,
I anoint the bodies of all the Mighty Sages,
Gleaming and radiant like pure refined gold.

To the supreme object of worship, the mighty sage,
I offer pleasing flowers - mandarava and lotus,
Utpala and all other fragrant blooms,
Along with beautiful, delightful garlands.

I offer to them also clouds of incense,
Whose supreme fragrance pervades and captivates the mind.

Various foods and drinks, along with divine offerings,
I shall also present to them.

I offer precious lamps
Like golden lotuses in full bloom.

On the ground spread out and anointed with incense,
Let beautiful, pleasing flowers be scattered.

tags:


In the immeasurable palace resounding with melodious praise,
Adorned with dangling pearl and jewel ornaments blazing beautifully,
Those boundless sky-decorations too,
I offer to the one of compassionate nature.

Beautiful precious parasols with golden handles,
Adorned with lovely ornaments around the rim,
Gracefully shaped and pleasing to behold when raised aloft,
I offer these constantly to the mighty sages.

Furthermore, may there be clouds of offerings:
Melodious music and pleasing songs,
Each appearing distinctly,
To satisfy and relieve the sufferings of sentient beings.

tags:


May a continuous shower of precious flowers and other offerings
Unceasingly rain down upon
All the sacred Dharma jewels,
The stupas, and the holy images.

tags:


Just as Manjushri and others
Offered worship to the Victorious Ones,
In the same way, I offer worship
To the Tathagatas, the Protectors, along with their Sons.

I praise the oceans of noble qualities
With oceans of melodious hymns of praise.

tags:


May those melodious clouds of praise
Certainly arise everywhere.

tags:


To all the Buddhas of the three times,
To the supreme Dharma and the noble Sangha,
With as many bodies as atoms in all realms,
I bow down and pay homage.

I prostrate to the foundations of bodhicitta,
And to all the stupas.

I pay homage to the abbot, the teacher,
And to those of supreme spiritual discipline.
Until I attain the essence of enlightenment, I take refuge in the Buddhas.
I also take refuge in the Dharma and in the assembly of Bodhisattvas.

To all the perfectly enlightened Buddhas and bodhisattvas
Who dwell in all directions,
Possessing great compassion,
I join my palms together and pray:

tags:


From beginningless time in samsara,
In this life or in other lives,
The negative actions I have committed unknowingly,
Or caused others to commit,
Or rejoiced in when committed by others,
Overcome by ignorance and delusion -
All these transgressions I now see and acknowledge.
I sincerely confess to the Protector.

To the Three Jewels, my parents, teachers, and others,
Whatever harm I have done through body, speech, and mind,
Driven by afflictive emotions;
And whatever grave misdeeds I, a sinner,
Have committed, stained by numerous faults,
All these utterly unbearable actions,
I confess to all the guides.

tags:


Before I have purified my negative karma,
I may face death prematurely.

Just as [we seek] certain liberation from this [samsara],
I pray for swift protection [on the path].

This Lord of Death cannot be trusted;
He does not wait for what is done or undone.

Whether sick or healthy, for everyone,
Life is suddenly unreliable.

Though one must depart leaving everything behind,
I did not understand this.

For the sake of friends and enemies,
Various kinds of misdeeds have been committed.
Even enemies will cease to exist.
Even loved ones will cease to exist.
I too will become non-existent.
Thus, everything becomes non-existent.

Like experiencing a dream,
Whatever objects one engages with,
Those become the objects of memory.
All that has passed cannot be seen again.

Even in this single lifetime,
Many friends and enemies have passed away.

The unbearable sins committed for their sake
Stand before me now.

Thus, not realizing
That I am impermanent,
Through ignorance, attachment, and anger,
I have committed many kinds of misdeeds.

Without pause, day and night,
This life constantly diminishes.

If there is no savior coming from elsewhere,
How can I not become subject to death?

tags:


Though I lie on my deathbed,
Surrounded by all my loved ones and friends,
The experience of my life-force ceasing
I alone must undergo.

When seized by the messenger of death,
What benefit are relatives?
What use is a friend?

At that time, if even a single merit were to be accumulated,
I did not rely on that either.

O Protector, I, being heedless,
Did not foresee such fears.
For the sake of this impermanent life,
I have committed many sins.

To the place where people's limbs are cut off,
Even today they are led with fear and trembling.

When dry mouth, bloodshot eyes, and other such signs
Appear to change from how they were before,

Seized by terrifying messengers of the Lord of Death,
With fierce and frightening appearances.

Those struck by the great terrifying disease,
What need is there to mention their extreme suffering?

Who will protect me well
From this great fear?
With eyes wide open in excitement and anticipation
Seeking refuge in the four directions.

Seeing no refuge in the four directions,
Then one becomes utterly discouraged.

If there is no refuge in that place,
Then what shall I do at that time?

Therefore, to the Victorious One, Protector of beings,
Who strives for the welfare of saving beings,
The mighty one who dispels all fears,
From this very day, I go for refuge.

The Dharma realized in their mind
Dispels the fears of samsara.
Likewise, I also take genuine refuge
In the assembly of bodhisattvas.

Terrified by fear,
I offer myself completely to Samantabhadra.

To Manjushri, I myself
Offer my own body.

To the protector Avalokiteshvara,
Whose compassionate conduct is unerring,
I cry out with the anguished voice of one in distress.
I, who am full of misdeeds, beseech you for protection.

tags:


To the noble Essence of Space,
And to the Essence of Earth,
And to all the great compassionate protectors,
I go for refuge.
Cry out from the depths of one's heart.

tags:


To the Vajra-holder I go for refuge,
Seeing whom the messengers of Death
And other hostile forces
Flee in terror to the four directions.
In the past, I transgressed your command.

Now, having seen great fear,
I come to you for refuge.
Swiftly remove all fears, I pray.

Even when frightened by ordinary illness,
One must follow the doctor's words.
What need is there to mention
Those constantly afflicted by the diseases
Of a hundred faults like desire and so forth?

Even that single one
Can destroy all people
Dwelling in this world.

tags:


If other medicines to heal those afflictions
Cannot be found in any direction,
Then not following the instructions
Of the All-Knowing Physician
Who removes all pain and suffering
Is extremely foolish and blameworthy.

Even on a small, ordinary precipice,
One must remain vigilant and careful.
What need is there to mention
The long fall into an abyss thousands of leagues deep?

Thinking "I will not die today,"
It is unwise to dwell in comfort.

The time when I cease to exist
Will surely come without fail.

Who has given me fearlessness?
How can I be certain of liberation from this?
If it is inevitable that I will cease to exist,
How can my mind remain at ease?

From what I have experienced and destroyed in the past,
What more do I have left?
Yet I cling to it with attachment,
And thus transgress the guru's instructions.

In this life and likewise,
Having abandoned relatives and friends,
When one must go alone to the next life,
What use are loved ones and enemies?

From non-virtue, suffering arises.
How can one be certain to be free from it?
Day and night, constantly,
I should contemplate this alone.

Due to my ignorance and delusion,
Whatever misdeeds I have committed,
Whether naturally wrong or prohibited by precept,
I confess them all before the Protector.
With palms joined in reverence,
Filled with sorrow and fear of suffering,
I bow down again and again,
And fully acknowledge all these faults.

tags:


I beseech the guides to grasp my misdeeds and faults as they truly are.

This is not good;
Henceforth, I shall never do it again.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
The second chapter, on confessing misdeeds.

I rejoice with gladness
In the virtuous deeds that relieve
The sufferings of lower realms
For all sentient beings,
And in the abiding in happiness
Of those who have known suffering.

I rejoice in the accumulation of virtue
That becomes the cause of enlightenment.

I rejoice in the definite liberation
From the sufferings of samsara for embodied beings.

I rejoice in the enlightenment of the protectors,
And also in the grounds of the bodhisattvas.

With an ocean of virtuous thoughts
That bring happiness to all beings,
And with joy I rejoice
In actions that benefit sentient beings.

tags:


To all the Buddhas of every direction,
With palms joined, I make this request:
For sentient beings lost in the darkness of suffering,
Please kindle the lamp of Dharma.

When the Victorious One wished to pass into nirvana,
With palms joined in prayer, this supplication was made:
"Do not leave these beings in blindness,
We beseech you to remain for countless eons."

Thus, having done all these things,
Whatever virtue I have accumulated,
By this, may all the sufferings
Of all sentient beings be removed.

For as long as beings are sick,
Until their illnesses are healed,
May I serve as their medicine, their doctor,
And their nurse who tends to them.

Having caused a rain of food and drink to fall,
May the sufferings of hunger and thirst be removed.

During the intermediate age of famine,
May I become food and drink.

For sentient beings who are poor and destitute,
May I become an inexhaustible treasure.

May various necessary implements and provisions
Be readily available before me.

My body, my possessions,
And all my virtues of the three times,
For the sake of accomplishing the welfare of all sentient beings,
I shall give away without hesitation.
By renouncing everything, one transcends sorrow.
I strive to achieve nirvana (liberation from suffering).

While giving up everything all at once,
The supreme gift is giving to all sentient beings.

I have already given this body
For the well-being of all sentient beings.

Even if one is constantly killed, reviled,
Or beaten and so on, as others please,

Even if they play with my body,
Or use it as a cause for mockery and insult,
I have already given this body away.
What is the use of this advice?

Whatever actions do not cause harm,
Allow them to be done.

May no one ever, at any time,
Focusing on me, become purposeless.

Whoever focuses on me
With thoughts of anger or devotion,
May that very act always become
The cause for fulfilling all their aims.

Whether some speak ill of me,
Or others cause me harm,
Or even if they mock and jeer,
May all attain enlightenment.

I am the protector of those without protection,
The guide for those who have entered the path,
The boat and
The raft and bridge for those who wish to cross over.

For those who seek a continent, may I be a continent;
For those who desire a dwelling place, may I be a dwelling place;
For myself, desiring to be a servant to all beings,
May I become a servant to all.

tags:


Like a wish-fulfilling jewel, an excellent vase,
A realized mantra, a great medicine,
A wish-granting tree,
May I become a fulfiller of the desires of all sentient beings.

tags:


Like the earth and other great elements,
And like space itself, may I always be
The basis for the diverse needs
Of countless, immeasurable beings.

Just as space extends to the farthest reaches,
May I be a source of sustenance
For all sentient beings in every realm,
Until they all attain nirvana.

Just as the previous Sugatas (Buddhas)
Generated the mind of enlightenment,
And progressively dwelt
In the training of bodhisattvas,
Likewise, for the benefit of beings,
I shall generate the mind of enlightenment,
And gradually train in the bodhisattva practices.

Likewise, regarding the training,
One should train step by step.

Thus, those endowed with wisdom,
Having firmly grasped the mind of enlightenment,
In order to further expand it in the end,
Should praise and encourage the mind in this way.
Today my life has borne fruit.
Having obtained a precious human rebirth
Today I am born into the family of the Buddhas.
Today, I have become a child of the Buddha.

Now I shall, by all means,
Undertake actions in accordance with my lineage.

In this faultless monastic lineage,
One should act so as not to become defiled.

Just as a blind person might find a precious jewel
In a heap of rubbish,
So too, by some coincidence,
This awakening mind has arisen within me.

This is also the supreme nectar
That conquers the lord of death for beings.

This is also the inexhaustible treasure
That dispels the poverty of beings.

This is also the supreme medicine
That pacifies the greatest illnesses of beings.

You are the tree of rest for weary beings
Who wander exhausted on the path of existence.

It is the universal vehicle that liberates
All beings from the lower realms.

The moon of the mind has risen,
Dispelling the torment of beings' afflictions.

The great sun that thoroughly dispels
The cataracts of ignorance in beings.

From churning the milk of the sacred Dharma,
The essence of butter has emerged.

Wandering as a guest on the path of existence,
Desiring to enjoy the pleasures of happiness,
This is the supreme abode of bliss:
Satisfying the great guests, all sentient beings.

tags:


Today, in the presence of all protectors,
I invite beings to the state of the Sugatas,
And in the meantime, I invite them as guests to happiness.
May the gods, demigods, and others be delighted.

From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the third chapter, called "Fully Embracing the Awakening Mind."

Thus, the child of the Victor,
Having firmly grasped the awakening mind,
Should strive diligently at all times without distraction
To never transgress the trainings.

Whatever has been hastily undertaken,
Or whatever has not been well examined,
Even if one has made a commitment to it,
It is proper to reconsider whether to do it or abandon it.

The Buddhas and their spiritual heirs,
Through their great wisdom have examined and realized...

Having thoroughly examined myself,
What excuse could there be for delay?

If, having made such a vow,
One does not fulfill it through action,
Having deceived all those sentient beings,
What will become of my own journey?

Even for the smallest ordinary thing,
If one merely thinks of giving in one's mind,
Yet does not actually give -
It is said that person will become a hungry ghost.

So if one invites beings as guests
With heartfelt intention to the supreme bliss,
But then deceives all beings,
How could one possibly go to a happy rebirth?

Even those who have abandoned the enlightened mind,
They too can be liberated.
The ways of karma are inconceivable.
Only the Omniscient One knows all.

For a bodhisattva, this is considered
The most serious among downfalls.

tags:


Thus, if this were to occur,
It would be inferior for the benefit of all sentient beings.

Whoever obstructs even for a moment
The merit of this [bodhisattva],
By diminishing the welfare of sentient beings,
Their descent into lower realms will be endless.

tags:


If destroying even one being's happiness
Causes oneself to decline,
What need is there to mention destroying
The happiness of limitless beings filling all of space?

Thus, when one alternates between powerful downfalls
And powerful bodhicitta (awakening mind),
One will take a long time
To attain the grounds (levels of realization).

Therefore, just as I have vowed,
I shall respectfully accomplish it.

If you do not strive diligently from now on,
You will sink lower and lower.

Although countless Buddhas who benefit all sentient beings
Have come and gone,
Due to my own faults,
I have not become an object of their healing care.

If one continues to act in this way,
Again and again it will be the same.

In the lower realms, one will experience
Illness, bondage, being cut, being split, and so forth.

The arising of a Tathagata (Buddha),
Faith, obtaining a human body,
And the opportunity to practice virtue -
Such rare occurrences, when will they be obtained?

Though we may have days free of illness like this,
And food without harm or violence,
Still, life itself is deceptive, lasting but a moment.
The body is like a temporary illusion.

With conduct such as this,
I will not even attain a human body.

If one does not obtain a human body,
There is only negativity, no virtue.

When I have the fortune and ability to practice virtue,
Yet I myself do not perform virtuous deeds,
Then when I face the suffering and delusion of lower realms,
What will I be able to do at that time?

If one has not performed virtuous deeds,
But has accumulated many negative actions,
Even after a hundred billion eons,
One will not even hear the sound of a fortunate rebirth.

Therefore, the Blessed One has said:
Like a turtle's neck passing through a hole
In a yoke floating on the great ocean,
Attaining human birth is extremely rare.

Even by a single moment's evil deed,
One may dwell in the Avici hell for an eon.
Given the evil accumulated since beginningless samsara,
Need it be said one will not go to higher realms?

tags:


Having experienced only that much,
One does not attain complete liberation.

Thus, while experiencing this,
Other sins proliferate rapidly.

Having obtained such leisure and opportunity,
If I do not practice virtue,
There is no greater deception than this.
There is no greater delusion than this.

If, having realized this truth,
I later become lazy due to delusion,
Then at the time when death approaches,
Great sorrow will arise.

tags:


If my body is burned for a long time
By the unbearable fires of hell,
Then undoubtedly my mind will be tormented
By the blazing flames of unbearable regret.

Having somehow obtained this extremely rare and beneficial ground,
If I, while possessing awareness,
Am led back again to those hells,
Then I must be as if bewildered by a spell,
For I am utterly mindless in this matter.
How deluded am I, for I do not know.
What is there within me?

Enemies like anger and desire
Have no arms or legs,
Yet without bravery or wisdom,
How have they enslaved me?

While dwelling in my mind,
Those who harm me with joy and delight,
To them I shall not be angry, but patient.
Patience towards the undeserving is a cause for reproach.

Even if all the gods and demigods
Were to rise up against me as enemies,
They still would not be able
To lead me into and cast me into the fires of Avici hell.

This powerful enemy of afflictive emotions,
When encountered, even Mount Meru
Would be reduced to nothing but dust.
In an instant, it casts me aside.

My afflictive emotions, which are like enemies,
Seem to have no beginning or end, lasting for a long time.
All other enemies are not like that -
They cannot endure for such a long duration.

If one relies on harmonious rituals,
All will bring benefit and happiness.
But if one relies on afflictive emotions,
They will only bring suffering and harm again and again.

Thus, if that which has long been a constant enemy,
The sole cause of the increase of a multitude of harms,
Certainly takes up residence in my heart,
How can I be fearless and joyful in samsara?

These guardians of samsara's prison, who have become murderous executioners in hell and other realms,
If they remain entangled in the web of attachment in my mind,
How can there be any happiness for me?

Thus, for as long as I have not directly and decisively defeated this enemy,
I will not abandon my efforts here.

Those who become angry even at minor harms,
The proud and arrogant ones cannot sleep without destroying them.

tags:


Those afflictions that cause suffering due to their inherent nature of death,
When facing them in battle, wishing to forcefully destroy them,
Even enduring the pain of being struck by arrows, spears and weapons,
If one does not flee or retreat without accomplishing the goal,

Then for me, who strives to defeat the certain enemy of inherent nature,
Which is always the cause of all suffering,
How much more needless to say that I will not become discouraged or disheartened
By any of the hundreds of sufferings that may arise as a result.

Even when a meaningless enemy inflicts wounds,
If one can wear them like ornaments on the body,
Then why should suffering harm me
When I strive diligently for a great purpose?

Fishermen, butchers, farmers and the like,
Who think only of their own livelihood,
Endure the harms of cold and heat and such.
So why should I not endure for beings' happiness?

When I vowed to liberate all beings
Throughout the ten directions to the ends of space
From their afflictions,
While I myself was not yet free
From my own afflictions,
How was this not the speech of a madman,
Not even knowing my own capacity?

Thus, to conquer afflictions,
One should never turn back.

To this I cling and grasp,
Holding grudges and engaging in battle.
Such afflictions of the mind
Are conquered only by the destroyer of afflictions.

Even if I am burned and killed,
Even if my head is cut off, so be it.
But in no way whatsoever
Will I bow down to the enemy of afflictive emotions.

Though ordinary enemies may be driven from the land,
They can dwell in other places and gather strength,
Then return once their power is restored.
But the enemy of afflictive emotions is not like that.
Abandon afflictions with the eye of wisdom.
Where will my mind go when it departs from me?
From where do they come to harm me?
In truth, I lack diligence in detaching my mind from self-clinging.

tags:


Afflictions do not reside in objects, nor in the sense faculties, nor in between.

tags:

If it is not other than this, where do these abide? They harm all beings.
This is like an illusion, therefore abandon fear in your heart. In order to understand this, rely on diligence.
Why do you harm me needlessly in the hells and other such realms?

Having contemplated thus, as has been explained,
One should strive diligently for the sake of accomplishing the training.

If one does not listen to the doctor's words,
How can a patient who needs treatment be cured by medicines?

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
This is the fourth chapter, called "Teaching on Carefulness."

Those who wish to guard their training,
Should diligently protect their mind.

If this mind is not guarded,
One cannot possibly guard the precepts.

Like an untamed elephant causing harm in Avici hell,
The uncontrolled mind, when let loose, creates similar damage.
Yet even a wild, intoxicated elephant
Does not inflict such harm in this world.

If one firmly binds the elephant of the mind
With the rope of mindfulness,
All fears will cease to exist.
All virtues come to hand.

Tigers, lions, elephants, and bears;
Snakes and all enemies;
The guardians of hell realms;
Witches and likewise demons;
By taming this mind alone,
All of these will be tamed.

By taming this mind alone,
All of those [afflictions] will be tamed.

Thus, all fears
And immeasurable sufferings
Arise from the mind,
As taught by the Perfect One.

Who deliberately created
The weapons of hell beings?
Who made the scorched earth of iron?
From what did those masses of fire arise?
The Sage (Buddha) taught that all such things are sinful thoughts.

Thus, in all three worlds,
There is no fear other than that arising from the mind.

If giving away all beings to poverty
Is the perfection of generosity,
Then how did the Protectors reach perfection
When there were still poor beings before?

Offering all one's possessions with their fruits,
To all beings with a generous mind,
Is proclaimed as the perfection of giving.
Therefore, that is mind itself.

Fish and other such creatures,
Drive them away without killing them.

It is said that the perfection of moral discipline
Comes from the mind of renunciation.

Like space, unruly beings are limitless;
They cannot all be overcome.

If one conquers this angry mind,
It is like defeating all enemies.

To cover all this earth with leather,
Where could so much leather be found?

A piece of leather the size of a shoe sole
Is like covering the entire surface of the earth.

Likewise, external objects
Cannot be reversed by oneself.

I must turn back this mind of mine;
What need is there to turn back others?

Just as a single moment of clear mind
Can result in rebirth as Brahma and such,
The fruits of physical and verbal actions
Are not like that due to weak conduct.

Though one may practice recitations and austerities
For a long period of time,
If done with a distracted mind,
The wise say it is meaningless.

If one does not know this secret of the mind,
Which is the supreme essence of the Dharma,
Though one desires to attain happiness and overcome suffering,
They will wander aimlessly without purpose.

Therefore, this mind of mine
Should be well grasped and well guarded.

Other than the discipline of guarding the mind,
What use are many other disciplines?

If dwelling amidst countless dangers,
One should be vigilant, as if guarding a wound.
Likewise, when living among wicked people,
One should constantly protect the wound of the mind.

tags:


If one is frightened by the small suffering of a wound,
And takes precautions against wounds,
Then why not guard against the mental wounds
Of fear, destruction, and ruin?

If one abides by such conduct,
Whether dwelling among evil people,
Or even residing among women,
The steadfast practitioner's vows will not deteriorate.

May my gains and honors be lost,
May my body and livelihood perish,
And may other virtues decline,
But may my mind never deteriorate.

For those who wish to guard their minds,
Mindfulness and vigilant awareness
Should be protected with all effort.
Thus, I join my palms in this way.

Just as people afflicted by illness
Are powerless in all their actions,
Likewise, those whose minds are disturbed by ignorance
Are powerless in all their actions.

For those with a mind lacking mindfulness,
Even their learning, contemplation, and meditation
Are like water in a leaky vessel -
They do not remain in memory.

Though many are learned, faithful,
And diligent in their practice,
Due to the flaw of lacking mindfulness,
They become tainted with downfalls.

Those who lack mindfulness are like thieves,
Following in the footsteps of lost awareness.
Though they may accumulate merit,
It is stolen away, and they go to lower realms.

This assembly of afflictive emotions and thieves
Is seeking opportunities and openings.
When an opportunity is found, virtue is snatched away.
It destroys even the life force of beings in fortunate realms.

Therefore, through the door of mindfulness,
Never let it stray away.

Even if one goes to lower realms of existence,
By recollecting and applying mindfulness,
One can overcome harm and suffering.

From associating with the lama,
Through the teachings given by the preceptor,
And due to reverence born of awe in those of good fortune,
Mindfulness arises with ease.

The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas
Possess unobstructed vision everywhere.
I am always in their presence,
Thus I reflect and think.
With shame, respect, and fear,
I abide in this way.
Therefore, the recollection of the Buddhas
Arises in me again and again.

When mindfulness remains at the gate of the mind
For the purpose of protection,
Then alertness will arise,
And even that which has gone will return.

For now, first recognize this kind of mind
As flawed and defective.
Then, at that time, I shall remain
Steadfast like a tree.
I will never engage in pointless distractions.

With mindful awareness at all times,
One should look with downcast eyes.

In order to rest one's eyes,
One should occasionally look to the side.

When someone appears before your eyes,
Look at them and say, "It's good that you've come."

To examine dangers on the path and elsewhere,
Look repeatedly in the four directions.

When resting, look back and observe
The direction behind you.

After carefully examining front and back,
One should either go or come.

Thus, in all circumstances,
One should act with understanding of the purpose.

Having restrained the body's actions, saying
"The body should remain in this way,"
Then, from time to time, one should observe:
"In what state is this body abiding?"

tags:


The intoxicated elephant of the mind
Should be firmly tethered
To the great pillar of contemplating the Dharma,
So it does not break loose.
Thus, strive with all your effort.

tags:


In order that meditative concentration may be diligent,
Not letting even a single moment slip away,
I will examine my mind repeatedly, asking:
"Where is my mind wandering now?"

If one is unable to relate to fear, celebration, and so on,
Do whatever brings ease.

Thus, at the times of giving,
It is taught to practice morality with equanimity.

Whatever one has decided to do,
One should not think of anything else.

With focused intention and mindfulness,
One should practice that very thing for a while.
Thus, all is well done.
Otherwise, it will not become both.

Without mindfulness, afflictive emotions
Will not increase in this way.

When engaging in various idle chatter,
And many wondrous spectacles,
As one becomes involved in all of these,
One should abandon attachment to them.

If one engages in pointless activities like digging the earth, cutting grass,
Or drawing on the ground and so forth,
Remembering the precepts of the Tathagata (Buddha),
One should immediately abandon such acts out of fear.

When you wish to move,
Or when you desire to speak,
First examine your own mind,
Then act with steadiness and awareness.

tags:


When one's own mind desires attachment and anger,
At that time, one should not act.
Do not speak.
Remain still like a tree.

tags:


When faced with laughter and mockery,
Or if filled with pride and arrogance,
Or with thoughts of exposing others' faults,
Or if intending to deceive or mislead,
When inclined to praise oneself,
Or to criticize and disparage others,
Along with harsh words and regret,
At such times, remain still like a tree.

If one desires gain, honor, and fame,
Or wishes to acquire servants and attendants,
Or if one's mind longs for respect and reverence,
At that time, one should remain still like a tree.

When the mind arises that wishes to:
Abandon the welfare of others,
Pursue one's own interests,
Or speak unnecessarily,
At that time, one should remain still like a tree.

When impatience, laziness, and fear arise,
As well as recklessness, idle chatter,
And attachment to one's own side,
At that time, remain still like a tree.

Thus, having examined the afflicted and purposeless striving mind,
At that time, the hero should firmly grasp it
Through the antidote.

With utmost certainty and deep faith,
Steadfast, respectful, and courteous,
Possessing modesty and a sense of shame,
Peaceful and striving to bring joy to others.

Not weary of the conflicting desires
Of childish beings at odds with each other,
When afflictions arise in them,
Think "This mind has arisen" with compassion.
Toward blameless phenomena,
Controlled by self and sentient beings,
Like an illusion, without ego,
Always hold this mind.

After a long time, having obtained this supreme leisure,
Contemplating it again and again,
One should hold the mind steady and unmoved,
Like Mount Meru, in this way.

Though vultures, attached to flesh,
May drag each other everywhere,
If your mind does not become displeased,
Why do you now give advice?

Having grasped this body as one's own,
Why, O mind, do you protect it?

When you and this are separate,
What can it do to you?

O deluded mind, why do you not grasp
The pure form of the wooden image?

This machine of impure aggregates,
What use is there in guarding this decaying thing?

First, this layer of skin,
By one's own mind, is separated as distinct.

From the web of flesh and bone,
Separate with the sword of wisdom.

Even the bones should be separated,
And examined down to the marrow.

What essence is there in this?
Examine it yourself thoroughly.

Though you have searched diligently,
If you have not seen its essence,
Why do you still, with attachment,
Protect this body?

You should not eat impure things.
You should not drink blood.
You should not even examine intestines.
So what use is this body to you?

At night, the fox and vulture
Should guard this for the sake of food.

This human body of ours
Is merely a vessel to be used.

Though you may guard it so,
The merciless Lord of Death
Will snatch it away and give it to birds and dogs.
At that time, what can you do?

Even if servants cannot be employed,
If clothing and such are not given,
When this body, though cherished, goes elsewhere,
Why do you exhaust yourself so?

Having given this payment,
Now let them do their own work.
Without benefit, one should not give everything away.

Viewing the body merely as a vessel,
Like a boat for coming and going.

For the sake of accomplishing the welfare of sentient beings,
May I transform into a wish-fulfilling body.
Thus, with freedom
Always maintain a smiling countenance.
Release all frowns, scowls, and gloomy expressions.
Be an honest friend to all beings.

One should not carelessly throw down chairs and such
With a loud noise.
Do not open the door too forcefully.
Always rejoice in humility.

Like an otter, a cat, or a thief,
Moving silently and stealthily,
To accomplish one's desired aim -
The sage should always act in this way.

Skilled in exhorting others,
Speech that brings benefit without being asked,
Should be respectfully received with the crown of one's head.
Always be a student of everyone.

For all that is well-spoken,
One should say, "This is virtuous speech."

When you see someone performing virtuous deeds,
Praise them sincerely and generate joy.

Speak of virtues in their absence,
And when virtues are spoken of, repeat them in agreement.

If one speaks of one's own qualities,
Know that this is understood as a virtue.
All endeavors are for the sake of joy.
That is rare even if bought with a price.

Therefore, through the virtues created by others,
One should experience the joy of happiness.

I have no misfortune here,
And in the hereafter, great happiness awaits.

Through wrongdoing, one becomes unhappy and suffers.
And in the hereafter, there is even greater suffering.

When speaking, be relaxed and coherent,
Clear in meaning and pleasing to the mind.
Free from attachment and aversion,
Speak gently and in moderation.

Even when looking at sentient beings with the eyes,
Relying on these very beings,
I will become a Buddha myself, thus
Look with honesty and loving-kindness.

Whether arising from constant attachment,
Or stirred by its antidote,
Benefiting others and cultivating virtues
Becomes a great virtue for those who suffer.

Having become wise and diligent,
I shall always perform all actions myself.
For all actions, one should not depend on anyone else.

Practice the perfection of generosity and the others,
Progressing higher and higher in excellence.
Do not give up something great for the sake of something small.
Primarily, consider the welfare of others.

Having understood thus, one should always
Remain diligent in benefiting others.

Through the far-reaching vision of one who possesses compassion,
Even those things which were forbidden are permitted for that purpose.

Share with those who have fallen into wrong views,
Those without protectors,
And those abiding in spiritual disciplines.
Eat in moderation.
Give everything except the three robes.

The sacred Dharma is the body of practice.
Do not harm it for trivial reasons.

By doing so, the wishes of sentient beings
Will be quickly fulfilled.

Without pure compassionate intention,
One should not give up this body.

In this life and in others to come,
May this be given as a cause for accomplishing great purpose.
Do not teach the Dharma to those who are disrespectful.

Not for those who, though not ill:
Wrap their heads, carry parasols,
Hold staffs or weapons,
Or cover their heads.

Humble yet profound and vast,
Neither man nor woman, for there is no birth.

Toward all dharmas, both lowly and supreme,
Practice with equal reverence in all ways.

One who has become a vessel for the vast Dharma
Should not engage in inferior teachings.
Do not completely abandon your conduct.
Do not be led astray by sutras and mantras.

When discarding toothsticks and spittle,
One should cover them.

Discarding urine and other bodily waste
In water or on dry land for enjoyment
Is condemned.

Do not eat with a full mouth, making noise,
Or with your mouth wide open.
Do not sit with legs stretched out.
Do not rub your hands together idly.

In vehicles, beds, seats, and dwellings,
Do not be alone with another's wife.

All those in the world who have lost faith
Should be abandoned after seeing and questioning.
Do not make gestures with your fingers.

With respect, everyone should
Use their right hand
To point out the way.
Do not move your hands excessively.

Move slightly and make a sound,
Give signals like snapping fingers and so on.
Otherwise, it will become unrestrained.

Like the Protector who passed into nirvana,
One should lie down facing the desired direction.

Swiftly arise with mindfulness,
And from the very beginning, apply it diligently to the mind.

From the boundless practices of bodhisattvas that have been taught,
The practices for training the mind
Should certainly be engaged in for that duration.

Three times during day and night,
One should recite the Three Heaps (Confession).

By relying on the Victor and the bodhicitta,
The remainder of downfalls will be pacified.

Whether by one's own power or another's,
Whatever circumstances one may engage in,
Whatever training has been taught,
Strive diligently to train in those circumstances.
There is nothing that the children of the Victorious Ones (bodhisattvas) do not train in.

For the wise one who abides thus,
There is nothing that does not become merit.

Whether directly or indirectly,
Practice nothing other than benefiting sentient beings.

For the sake of sentient beings alone,
I dedicate all [merit] for the purpose of enlightenment.

Always seek a spiritual friend
Who is learned in the meaning of the Great Vehicle,
And supreme in the conduct of bodhisattvas.
Do not abandon them even at the cost of your life.

From the biography of Glorious Sambhava,
Learn the method of relying on the guru.

This and other teachings given by the Buddha
Should be understood by reading the sutras.
The trainings appear in the sutras.
Therefore, one should read the sutras.

The Sutra of the Essence of Space
Should be viewed first and foremost.

Because it is always practiced,
It is extensively taught from that.
The compendium of all trainings
Should certainly be examined again and again.

Alternatively, for now in brief,
Look at the collection extracted from all sutras.

These two [teachings] composed by the noble Nagarjuna
Should be studied with diligence.

Whatever is not prohibited,
That itself is to be practiced.

In order to protect the worldly mind,
Having seen the precepts, practice them perfectly.

Examine again and again
The state of your body and mind.
This alone, in brief,
Is the essence of maintaining mindfulness.
These should be practiced with the body.
What is accomplished by merely uttering words?

Does merely reading medical texts
Benefit the sick?

From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the fifth chapter, on guarding alertness.

The merit accumulated over a thousand eons
Through generosity, offerings to the Buddhas, and other virtuous deeds,
All of these positive actions
Can be destroyed by a single moment of anger.
There is no sin like hatred.
There is no austerity like patience.
Therefore, one should diligently cultivate patience in various ways.

If one harbors anger and resentment in the mind,
One will not experience peace of mind.
Joy and happiness will not be attained,
Sleep will not come, and stability will be lost.

Those who have been given wealth and honors,
And have come to rely on that benefactor,
Even they will turn against
That hostile master and seek to destroy him.
By that, friends become weary.
Even if attracted by generosity, one should not become dependent.

In short, there is no one at all
Who dwells in happiness while angry.

The enemy of anger and the like
Will bring about suffering.

One who diligently overcomes anger
Will be happy in this life and the next.

When unwanted actions occur
And desired ones are obstructed,
Finding nourishment in mental discomfort,
Anger grows strong and destroys the self.

Therefore, I shall utterly destroy
That enemy's food.

Thus, other than harming me,
This enemy has no other purpose.

Whatever befalls me,
I shall not disturb my joyful mind.
Even if you are displeased, desires will not be fulfilled.
Virtuous deeds will decline.

If it can be remedied,
Why be displeased about it?

If it cannot be changed,
What use is there in being displeased about it?

To myself or my friends,
Suffering, contempt, and harsh words,
And what is called unpleasant - these are not desired.
To enemies, do the opposite of that.
The causes of happiness arise only occasionally.
The causes of suffering are extremely numerous.
Without suffering, there is no renunciation.
Therefore, mind, resolve to be steadfast.

Overcoming difficulties with faith and devotion,
Enduring sensations of burning, cutting, and more,
I bear these meaningless sufferings
For the sake of liberation.

Why is there nothing
That does not become easy
When practiced before?
Indeed, no such thing exists.

Therefore, by becoming accustomed to small harms,
Learn to endure great harms.

Why have you not seen the pointless suffering
Caused by snakes and mosquitoes,
The sensations of hunger and thirst,
And afflictions like itching and the like?

To heat and cold, rain and wind,
To sickness, bondage and beatings,
I shall not be averse.
If one acts in that way, harm will increase.

Some, upon seeing their own blood,
Become even more courageous and steadfast.

Some people, upon seeing the blood of others,
Become faint and lose consciousness.

That is the result of a steady mind
And the transformation of previous habits.

Therefore, disregard harm,
And remain unaffected by sufferings.

Even when suffering arises, the wise
Do not disturb or agitate their minds.
Engage in battle with the afflictions.
In times of battle, there are many harms.

tags:


Having endured all sufferings,
Conquering enemies such as anger,
Those are the victorious heroes.
Killing the remainder on the corpse.

Furthermore, the virtues of suffering:
Through disillusionment, it dispels arrogance.
Generate compassion for those trapped in samsara.
Avoid evil and delight in virtue.

Why be angry at sentient beings,
When we do not rage against great sources
Of suffering like bile and the like?
All of these are prompted by conditions.

Just as illnesses arise
Even though we do not wish for them,
Likewise, afflictive emotions emerge
Forcefully, though we do not desire them.

Even without intending to be angry,
People become enraged and hostile.

Even without thinking "I should generate anger,"
Anger arises just the same.

All faults, however many there may be,
And various kinds of misdeeds,
All of these arise from the power of conditions.
There is no inherent self-existence.

Those assembled causes and conditions
Do not think "I shall produce an effect."

That which is produced does not think "I am produced."
There is no such thought or consciousness.

That which is conceived as the principal or chief,
And that which is imagined as the self,
This very self, thinking "I shall arise,"
Deliberately contemplates, yet does not arise.

If it does not exist before being born,
Then what is it that desires to be born?
That which is always distracted by objects
Does not cease to exist either.

If the self were permanent,
It would appear inactive, like space.

Even when encountering various conditions,
If there is no change, what can be done?

When acting, if it is as before,
What has been accomplished by that action?

What is there that can be connected,
Saying "This is its function"?
Thus, everything is dependent on others.
Due to that power, one is powerless.

When you understand this,
You will not become angry
At any phenomena,
Just as you would not be angry at a snake.
By what means should one prevent what?

If one argues that reversing [suffering] is not reasonable,
Then based on that, it would not be unreasonable
To desire that all sufferings be cut off at their source.

tags:


Therefore, whether enemy or friend,
If you see someone acting improperly,
Think: "This arose from such conditions."
Reflecting thus, remain at ease.

If things were accomplished by mere wishes,
Since no one desires suffering,
Then for all embodied beings,
Suffering would never arise for anyone.

Through carelessness, one harms even oneself,
As if stepping on thorns and other harmful things.

For the sake of obtaining women and such,
One becomes greedy and practices fasting and other austerities.

tags:


Some jump into chasms and fall to their death.
Some eat poisonous or harmful foods.
Some engage in non-virtuous actions.
In these ways, people bring harm upon themselves.

tags:


When under the influence of afflictive emotions,
One even harms and destroys oneself.
At such times, how could it be
That one would not harm others' bodies?

When afflictive emotions arise,
And one engages in self-harm and such,
If great compassion does not arise,
What use is there in becoming angry?

If harming others
Is the nature of childish beings,
It is not right to be angry at them.
Like a fire that burns by its own nature.

However, if these faults are temporary,
And beings are naturally gentle,
Then it is not right to be angry.
Like rare wisps of smoke in the sky.

If you become angry at a stick or other object that is thrown at you,
That anger is also driven by hatred.
Therefore, it is more appropriate to be angry at anger itself.

In the past, I have caused harm
To sentient beings in this way.

Therefore, it is fitting that this harm comes to me,
For I have harmed sentient beings.

Both their weapons and my body
Are causes of suffering.

Therefore, if my body is removed,
At whom should I be angry?

tags:


Like a human form made of thorns,
Unbearable to touch, full of suffering.
If I, blinded by desire, grasp onto it,
Who should I be angry at for the harm it causes?

Though children do not desire suffering,
They crave the causes of suffering.
When harmed by their own faults,
What reason is there to blame others?

For example, like the guardians of hell
And the forest of sword-like leaves,
These are produced by one's own karma.
At whom, then, should one be angry?

Through my own actions, I have summoned forth
Those who harm me and cause me suffering.

If by this, sentient beings go to hell,
Have I not destroyed them?

Relying upon these,
Through patience, many of my misdeeds arise.

Relying on me, they
For a long time will go to the suffering hell realms.

When I harm them,
Yet they bestow benefit upon me,
Why, for what reason,
Does my unruly mind become angry in reverse?

If I have virtuous qualities in my mind,
I will not go to hell.

tags:


If I protect myself,
What will happen to them here?

However, if harm is done in return,
Those [precepts] have not been protected,
And my own conduct will also deteriorate.
Therefore, austerities will be destroyed.

Since the mind is not corporeal,
No one can destroy it anywhere.

Due to strong attachment to the body,
The body is harmed by sufferings.

Though contempt, harsh words, and unpleasant speech
Do not physically harm the body,
Why, O mind, do you become so enraged?

If others who dislike me
Do not consume me
Either in this life or the next,
Why should I not wish for them?

If I do not desire this,
For it creates obstacles to attainment,
Then I shall abandon my gains here.
Sins remain firmly established.

It is better for me to die today
Than to live long through wrong livelihood.

Though the view of self may endure for a long time,
It is itself the suffering of death.

One who experiences happiness in a dream for a hundred years,
And then awakens;
Another who experiences happiness for just a moment,
And then awakens;
For both of these upon awakening,
That happiness does not return.

Whether life is long or short,
At the time of death, it ends just the same.

Though one may obtain many possessions,
And enjoy happiness for a long time,
Like being robbed by a thief,
One goes naked and empty-handed.

If one lives by gain,
And asks, "Should I exhaust sins and perform virtuous deeds?"
Yet becomes angry for the sake of gain,
Won't virtues be exhausted and sins not diminish?

If the very purpose for which I live
Should become corrupted or lost,
Then what use is this life
That only commits evil deeds?

If you become angry at those
Who speak unpleasant words that harm beings,
Why then do you not likewise become angry
At yourself when you speak unpleasantly to others?

If you can be patient with those who lack faith,
As their disbelief depends on other factors,
Why can't you be patient with harsh speech,
Since it depends on the arising of afflictions?

Even towards those who carelessly destroy
Sacred images, stupas, and holy scriptures,
It is not right for me to feel anger,
For the Buddhas and others cannot be harmed.

tags:


Even towards those who harm our teachers, relatives, and friends,
When we see that they are changed by circumstances,
Just as in the previous case,
We should reverse our anger.

If both sentient and non-sentient beings cause harm,
Why single out and blame only those with minds?
Therefore, practice patience with harm.
Some commit wrongdoing due to ignorance.

If someone becomes angry due to ignorance,
How can they be without fault?
What is it that has faults?

Why did you previously perform
Those actions that harm others?

If everything depends on karma,
Why should I be angry at this?

Having seen thus, by all means,
May everyone become mutually loving-minded.
In this way, I myself
Shall strive diligently in virtuous deeds.

For example, a fire that has burned a house,
Having gone to another house,
Spreads to whatever grass and such it finds there.
That [fire] is to be extinguished and discarded.

Likewise, when the mind becomes attached,
And the fire of anger flares up,
Fearing that merit will be burned away,
One should immediately abandon that [attachment].

If a condemned person's hand is cut off,
Yet they are able to escape, is that not good?

If human suffering
Could free beings from hell,
Would that not be excellent?

If I cannot even endure
This present suffering,
Then why do I not restrain anger,
The cause of hellish torments?

Though I may experience thousands of hells,
Burning and such for the sake of desires,
I have accomplished neither my own purpose
Nor the purpose of others.

tags:


This is not so harmful,
And great purposes will be accomplished.
For removing the harms and sufferings of beings,
One should rejoice in this alone.

When others praise someone's virtues,
If you gain joy and happiness from that,
Then your own mind, by praising likewise,
Why do you not feel such joy yourself?

This joy and happiness of yours,
Is a bliss arising without fault.
It is approved by those endowed with virtues.
It is also the supreme method of gathering others.

Furthermore, if you do not desire this happiness,
Which is said to bring about such bliss,

By abandoning offerings of payment and rewards,
Both the seen and unseen will deteriorate.

When speaking of one's own good qualities,
One should also wish for the happiness of others.

When praising the virtues of others,
One should not desire happiness for oneself.

tags:


Since all sentient beings desire happiness,
Having generated the mind of enlightenment,
If sentient beings find happiness themselves,
Why then should one become angry at that?

If sentient beings desire
To make offerings to the Three Worlds and attain enlightenment,
Why do they become distressed
Upon seeing only meager offerings and service?

Whatever patient you are treating,
You yourself should provide that treatment.
If a relative finds sustenance,
Do they not become angry again instead of pleased?

If one does not desire [to benefit] beings,
How can one desire enlightenment?

How can there be bodhicitta (the enlightened mind)
In one who becomes angry at another's prosperity?

If one obtains it from that,
Or dwells in the patron's house,
If you do not have it at all,
Whether given or not given, what use is it?

Why abandon merit and faith,
Or one's own good qualities?

Tell me, who does not become angry
When they do not obtain what they seek?

Not only do you feel no remorse for your own misdeeds,
But you even wish to compete
With others who have done virtuous acts.
This is the second volume.

Even if an enemy dislikes you,
What benefit is there in you disliking them?

By your mere aspiration,
It does not become a cause of harm to that.

Even if your desires are fulfilled,
What joy is there in your suffering?

If one becomes filled with pride,
What could be more ruinous than that?

This saliva cast by the fisherman of afflictions
Is an unbearable hook.

From then on, even in the hell-pot of the mind,
The guardians of hell will torment me.
Through praise and fame's offerings,
Merit will not increase, nor greatly change.
My strength will not increase, nor will I be free from illness.
The body will not become comfortable either.

If I understand my own purpose,
What self-interest could there be in that?

If you desire only happiness,
You must also rely on ornaments, alcohol, and such things.

For the sake of fame, wealth is lost,
And even one's own life is destroyed.
What use, then, are mere words?
Who finds peace in flesh?

When a sand castle collapses,
Children become distraught.
Likewise, when praise and fame decline,
One's own mind is like a child's.

For a moment, since sound has no mind,
It is impossible for it to have the intention to praise me.

That which is known as others' joy in me,
Is it not the cause of happiness?

Whether for others or even for oneself,
What benefit is there to me in others' happiness?

That joy and bliss is its own essence.
I cannot obtain a share from it.

If I wish for my own happiness,
I must likewise wish it for all.
How can I be happy
When others are not joyful?

Therefore, when one thinks "I am being praised,"
And feels joy arising within oneself,
That too is not reasonable,
It is merely childish behavior.
Praise and such things cause me to become distracted.
By that, even weariness is destroyed.

Jealousy towards those with good qualities
Destroys even perfect abundance.

Therefore, those who remain nearby
To destroy my praise and such,
Are they not engaged in protecting me
From falling into the lower realms?

tags:


I seek liberation;
I do not need to be bound by gain and honor.

How can I be angry at those
Who free me from my own bondage?

Though I wish to enter into suffering,
As if blessed by the Buddha,
The door has become unrelenting and will not open.
How can I be angry at this?

This is said to be an obstacle to merit;
Even towards that, anger is not appropriate.

Is there an austerity equal to patience?
If not, shall I not abide in that?

If I, due to my own faults,
Do not practice patience towards this,
Then I am merely creating obstacles for myself
Regarding this nearby cause of merit.

That which does not arise without something,
And which exists when that something exists,
If that very thing is its cause,
How can it be called an obstacle?

The beggar who arrives at the proper time
Has not obstructed the act of giving.

That which causes one to go forth,
Should not be called an obstacle to renunciation.

In this world, beggars are common,
But those who cause harm are rare.

If you do not harm others,
No one will harm you.

Therefore, like a treasure appearing in one's house
Without having to strive or labor for it,
Since they have become friends in the practice of enlightenment,
I should rejoice in my enemies.

By accomplishing this and myself,
Therefore, the fruit of patience
Should first be tested in this life.
Thus, this is the cause of patience.

If one thinks there is no need to cultivate patience,
And thus this enemy should not be honored,
Then why honor even the sublime Dharma,
Which is suitable as a cause for accomplishment?

If this enemy, intending to harm,
Is not worthy of veneration, you may say.
But if they strive to help, like a physician,
How then would my patience be perfected?

Therefore, since patience arises
In dependence on intense anger,
That very anger is the cause of patience.
Thus it is worthy of veneration, like the sacred Dharma.

Therefore, the Sage (Buddha) taught that
There are the realms of sentient beings
And the realms of the Victorious Ones (Buddhas).

Many who are pleased by these,
Thus reach the perfection of the far shore.

tags:


From sentient beings and the Victorious Ones,
The qualities of Buddhahood are equally achieved.
Just as we show respect to the Victorious Ones,
Why do we not do the same for sentient beings?

The qualities of one's thoughts are not from oneself;
They are the result of one's actions.
Likewise, sentient beings also possess virtuous qualities.
Therefore, those are equal.

To one endowed with loving-kindness, whatever offering is made,
That is the greatness of sentient beings.

tags:


Whatever merit arises from faith in the Buddha,
That too is the greatness of the Buddha.

tags:


The Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha are complete;
Therefore, they are considered equal.

Not equal to any of the Buddhas,
Who possess an infinite ocean of qualities.

tags:


Even if only a few partial qualities
Of the supreme collection of virtues
Appear in someone, to make offerings to them
Offering the three realms would be too little.

tags:


Since all sentient beings possess
A share of the supreme qualities of the Buddha's teachings,
By considering this aspect alone,
It is fitting to honor sentient beings as worthy of veneration.

Furthermore, to those who have become unwavering friends
And who perform immeasurable acts of benefit,
What else could repay them
Other than delighting sentient beings?

Because one who gives up their body and enters the Avīci hell
Will repay the kindness of those who have benefited them,
Therefore, even if these beings cause great harm,
One should practice only the utmost good towards all of them.

For a time, even my own master,
Who does not regard even his own body,
How can I, in my ignorance,
Be arrogant and not act as a servant?

Those who bring joy to the sages through happiness,
And those who, when harmed, cause the sages displeasure;
By delighting in them, all sages are pleased,
And harming them is like harming the sages themselves.

tags:


Just as a body completely engulfed in flames
Cannot be made happy by any desires,
Likewise, when harm is done to sentient beings,
There is no way for the greatly compassionate ones to be pleased.

Therefore, by harming sentient beings,
I have displeased those of great compassion.
Today I confess each of these misdeeds,
Whatever displeases you, I ask for your patience and forbearance.

In order to please the Tathagatas (Buddhas),
From this day forward, I shall be a servant to the world.

Though many beings may gather to trample me,
Even if I die, I will not retreat. May the Protector of the World be pleased.

All these beings are embraced by that compassionate one;
There is no doubt that he has made them his own.

These beings that I perceive in their true nature,
Why do I not revere them as the Protector himself?
This itself is what pleases the Tathagata.
This very [practice/teaching] accomplishes one's own true purpose as well.
This itself is what eliminates the suffering of the world.
Therefore, I shall always do just that.

For example, even if some of the king's men
Harm many people,
Those with far-sighted vision,
Though capable, do not retaliate.
Thus, this is not one.
The power of the king is his strength.
Likewise, do not despise or kill even the weakest of harmful beings.

Thus, the guardians of hell
And those endowed with compassion are its army.

Thus, like a benevolent ruler,
One should please all sentient beings.

Even if a king becomes angry,
The harm that is experienced
By displeasing sentient beings
Is equal to the torments of hell.

Even if a king is pleased,
By pleasing sentient beings,
Whatever one attains
Cannot be compared to bestowing Buddhahood itself.

From pleasing sentient beings,
Let alone attaining future Buddhahood,
Even in this very life,
Why not see great glory, fame and happiness arise?

While in samsara, through patience one is beautified and so forth.
Through being free of illness and having renown,
One attains extremely long life,
And obtains the expanding bliss of a universal monarch.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
This is the sixth chapter, called "Teaching on Patience".
Thus, with patience, one should undertake diligence.
Thus, through diligence, one abides in enlightenment.

Just as there is no movement without wind,
Merit does not arise without diligence and effort.
Diligence is joyfully engaging in virtue.
The opposing factors to that will be explained.

Attachment to harmful laziness,
And discouragement that belittles oneself.

Through savoring the taste of laziness's comfort,
And craving that relies on sleep,
One does not tire of samsara's suffering.
Thus, indolence is born nearby.

Ensnared by the net of afflictions,
Caught in the net of birth,
Having entered the maw of the Lord of Death,
How is it you still do not understand?

Have you not seen
How your own kind are gradually being killed?

However, those who rely on sleep
Are like outcasts and buffaloes.

With all paths blocked,
As the Lord of Death looks on,
How can you still eat with pleasure?
How can one sleep contentedly like this?

Since death will come swiftly,
For as long as possible, accumulate merit.

At that time, even if laziness is abandoned,
What is there to do when it is not the right moment?

When death suddenly comes
While this task is left undone,
And that one half-finished,
The mind laments, "Alas, I am ruined!"

With eyes reddened and face swollen by intense grief,
Tears stream down the cheeks.

When relatives lose hope,
Look upon the face of the messenger of death.

When tormented by remembering one's own sins,
And hearing the sounds of hell,
Terrified, with an unclean body and clothes,
What should one do when becoming intoxicated?

If you are filled with fear in this life,
Like a fish flopping on dry land,
What need is there to speak of
The unbearable sufferings of hell
That result from evil deeds?

When touched by hot water,
It is extremely hot to tender flesh.
Having committed actions leading to hell,
Why do you dwell so comfortably like this?

Those who desire results without effort,
And the lazy ones, encounter many harms.

tags:


Seized by death, like gods,
Alas! Crushed by sufferings.

Relying on the boat of human birth,
Cross over the great river of suffering.

tags:


This boat is difficult to find again,
So do not sleep in ignorance when the time comes.

Having abandoned the supreme joy of the holy Dharma,
Which is the limitless source of happiness,
Why do you delight in distractions
And frivolity that are causes of suffering?

Without laziness, with diligence and effort,
Exert control over yourself.
Equalize yourself and others,
And exchange yourself for others.

I should not become discouraged, thinking,
"How can I ever attain enlightenment?"

Thus, the Tathagata (Buddha),
Who speaks the truth, has spoken this truth.

Even flies, bees, and insects,
And likewise those who have become worms,
If they generate the power of diligence,
Will attain the difficult-to-achieve, unsurpassed enlightenment.

Born as a human with discerning wisdom,
Knowing what is beneficial and harmful,
If I do not abandon the practice of enlightenment,
How could I not attain enlightenment?
However, if I am afraid that I must give away my limbs and such,

Without examining what is heavy and what is light,
I, in my ignorance, am merely afraid.

For countless billions of eons,
Though one may be cut into pieces numerous times,
Pierced, burned, and torn apart,
One will not attain enlightenment.

The suffering I endure in pursuit of enlightenment
Is limited and measurable.

Like the pain of inflicting a wound on the body
To remove a harmful thorn lodged within,

All physicians, through their medical treatments,
Eliminate the illnesses of discomfort.

Therefore, to overcome many sufferings,
One should endure minor discomforts.

Such ordinary medical treatments
Are not performed by the supreme physician.

Through extremely gentle ritual practices,
Countless great illnesses are healed.

Even when offering vegetables and other foods,
The guide (Buddha) first performs the preparation.

Through becoming accustomed to that,
Later, gradually, one even gives away one's own flesh.

When one develops a mindset
Regarding one's own body
As something like a vegetable,
At that time, giving away flesh and so forth,
What difficulty is there in that?
In order to abandon wrongdoing, there is no suffering.
For the wise, there is no displeasure.

Thus, wrong views and negative actions
Harm both the mind and body.

Through merit, the body is at ease.
Through wisdom, the mind is at peace.
Though remaining in samsara for the sake of others,
How could the compassionate ones ever grow weary?

This is the power of the enlightened mind,
Which exhausts previous negative karma,
And gathers an ocean of merit.
Therefore, it is taught to be supreme, even surpassing the hearers.

Therefore, mounting the horse of bodhicitta,
Which dispels all weariness and fatigue,

Who with an understanding mind would become lazy
On the path that leads from happiness to happiness?

For the purpose of accomplishing the welfare of sentient beings,
The forces are aspiration, steadfastness, joy, and renunciation.

Faith arises from contemplating
The fears and sufferings [of samsara],
And the benefits [of liberation].

Thus, having abandoned opposing factors,
With devotion, pride, joy, and renunciation,
Through mastery, control, and strength,
One should strive to increase diligence.

I shall overcome countless faults,
Both my own and those of others.

Where even for a single wrongdoing,
An ocean of eons would be exhausted,
Yet not even a fraction of effort
To exhaust my misdeeds do I see in myself.
A place of immeasurable suffering -
Why does my heart not break?

I should accomplish many virtues
For myself and for others.

Even if each individual virtue
Is practiced for oceans of eons,
I have never developed
Even a fraction of such virtues.

How wonderful that I have found this birth,
Yet I have wasted it on meaningless pursuits.

tags:


If I have not worshipped the Blessed One,
Nor given the joy of a great festival,
Nor worked for the benefit of the Dharma,
Nor fulfilled the wishes of the poor,
Nor given fearlessness to the frightened,
Nor brought comfort to the suffering,
Then I have only produced
The pain and suffering of a mother's womb.

Due to my lack of faith in the Dharma,
Both in the past and even now,
I have fallen into such a state of poverty.
Who abandons devotion to the Dharma?

The Sage (Buddha) has proclaimed that faith
Is the root of all virtuous qualities.

The root of that is always
Meditating on the ripened fruit (karmic results).

Suffering, unhappiness, and
Various kinds of fears,
As well as separation from desires -
These arise from engaging in wrongful actions.

tags:


By performing virtuous deeds with mindful intention,
Wherever one may go,
There, through the merit of those actions,
One will be honored with the fruits of virtue.

Though one who commits evil deeds desires happiness,
Wherever they may go,
There, that evil
Destroys them with the weapon of suffering.
Dwelling in the heart of a vast, fragrant lotus

The glorious body nourished by the sweet nectar of the Buddha's speech,
Arising from the lotus expanded by the light of the Sage,
Standing before the Victorious One, through virtue becomes a child of the Tathagatas.
The being of the Lord of Death completely flayed off all the skin, causing extreme suffering and misery.

Molten copper, melted by intensely hot fire, is poured upon the body.
Flaming swords and short spears pierce the flesh, cutting it into a hundred pieces.
Falling onto an extremely blazing iron ground - these are the results of many negative deeds.

Therefore, one should be devoted to virtue,
And meditate with reverence.

Through the ritual of the vajra victory banner,
One should begin to meditate on pride.

First, examine your resources,
Then decide whether to undertake or not undertake [the task].

Not starting is best,
But once begun, do not turn back.

In other lifetimes, becoming habituated to that,
Negativity and suffering will increase.

Moreover, the time of fruition for others
Will become inferior, and that too will not be accomplished.

Actions, afflictions, and power:
Take pride in these three.

"I alone will do this" -
This is the very pride of action.

This world, powerless under the influence of afflictions,
Is unable to accomplish its own purpose.
Though beings cannot be like me,
Therefore, I shall do this.

When others engage in lowly deeds,
How am I myself any different?
Do not act out of pride.
The highest state is to be free of ego.

When encountering a dead snake,
Even a crow behaves like a garuda.

If one's self is weak,
Even a small mistake can cause harm.

Is there liberation from poverty
For those who abandon effort with discouragement?

By cultivating pride and exertion,
Even the great find it difficult to succeed.

Therefore, with a steadfast mind,
One should overcome all downfalls.

If I am defeated by downfalls,
My desire to conquer the three realms becomes laughable.
I shall be victorious over all.
Do not conquer anyone but yourself.

I, the child of the Victorious Lion,
Shall abide in this pride.
Those beings who are overcome by pride...
Afflictions are not prideful.
The arrogant do not fall under the power of enemies.
Those become subject to the enemy of pride.

Filled with the affliction of pride,
Pride leads one to lower realms.
It destroys human joy and celebration,
