Makes one a servant eating others' food,
Foolish, ugly, and weak.
Everywhere, one becomes despised.

Those who are full of pride and practice austerities,
If they too are counted among the prideful,
What can be said of how lowly the humble are?

Whoever holds pride in order to overcome the enemy of pride,
That one is indeed prideful and a victorious hero.
Whoever completely conquers even the arising of the enemy of pride,
May I accomplish the fruit of enlightenment according to the wishes of all beings.

If you dwell amidst afflictive emotions,
You will assume a thousand different forms of suffering.

Like a lion [unaffected] by foxes and such,
One should not be overcome by the hosts of afflictions.

Even when great misfortune befalls you,
Just as a person protects their eyes,
Likewise, even when misfortune occurs,
Do not fall under the power of afflictive emotions.

Even if I am burned and killed,
Or even if my head is cut off, so be it.
In all aspects, one should not bow down to the enemy of afflictions.

Likewise, in all circumstances,
One should not practice anything other than reason.

Like desiring the pleasant fruits of play,
What actions are to be done by this?
One should be attached to that action.
Be joyful and never satisfied with that action.

Though one acts for the sake of happiness,
Whether happiness will result or not is uncertain.

How can one be happy
By not doing that very action
Which brings about happiness?

Like honey on the edge of a razor,
If one is not satisfied by sensual pleasures,
How much less can one be satisfied
By virtuous deeds that ripen as peace and bliss?

Therefore, in order to complete the task,
Like an elephant scorched by the midday sun
Plunges into a lake upon encountering it,
One should likewise plunge into that task.

When strength is diminished and connection is lost,
One should abandon it in order to renew.

If one grasps it well, it is the hereafter.
Desiring the hereafter, one should abandon this.

Like facing an old enemy
On the battlefield with drawn swords,
One should dodge the weapons of afflictions
And strive to defeat the foes of mental defilements.

If a sword falls on the battlefield,
One quickly picks it up out of fear.
Likewise, if the weapon of mindfulness is lost,
Swiftly recollect the terrors of hell.

Just as poison spreads throughout the body
When it enters the bloodstream,
So too do faults pervade the mind
When they find an opportunity.

Carrying a vessel filled with mustard oil,
While a sword-bearer sits nearby.

Just as one fears the threat of death,
So should the disciplined practitioner strive diligently.

Therefore, just as one would quickly rise
If a snake came into one's lap,
Likewise, when sleep and laziness come,
One should swiftly turn them away.

For each fault that occurs,
Having criticized myself, by all means
So that this does not happen to me again in the future,
I will think long and hard about how to act accordingly.

Just as one becomes accustomed to mindfulness
In these temporary states,
Through this cause, one should desire
To encounter or engage in logical actions.

Before undertaking any action,
One should have the ability for all things.
Thus, mindful of careful speech,
One should rise up lightly oneself.

Just as the wind controls cotton,
Moving it to and fro,
So too does enthusiasm control us.
In this way, accomplishment arises.

From "Entering the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the seventh chapter, called "Teaching on Diligence".

Having thus generated diligence,
Place the mind in meditative concentration.

The mind of a distracted person
Dwells in the jaws of afflictive emotions.

Through seclusion of body and mind,
Distractions do not arise.

Therefore, abandon worldly concerns,
And completely relinquish conceptual thoughts.

Due to attachment and craving for gain and the like,
One does not renounce the world.

Therefore, completely abandon these [distractions],
And the wise should investigate in this way.

tags:


Knowing that special insight endowed with perfect calm abiding
Thoroughly destroys the afflictions,
One should first seek calm abiding.
This is accomplished through joy in detachment from worldly concerns.

Who among the impermanent does not cling
To that which is truly impermanent?

For thousands of lifetimes,
One will never again see suffering.
If not seen, one does not become happy.
The mind also does not remain in meditative equipoise.

tags:


Though one sees, one does not become satisfied.
As before, one becomes tormented by craving.

If one becomes attached to sentient beings,
It completely obscures the ultimate truth.
It also destroys the mind of weariness.
In the end, it leads to sorrow and anguish.

By mere thinking alone,
This life will pass without meaning.

By impermanent friends,
Even the eternal dharma will be destroyed.

If you associate with childish people and those of equal fortune,
You will certainly fall into lower realms.

If one leads unequally,
What use is there in relying on the childish?

In an instant, one can become a friend.
In a moment, one can also become an enemy.

By getting angry at joyful situations,
It is difficult for ordinary beings to be pleased.
When spoken to beneficially, they become angry.
I also act contrary to [my own] benefit.

If one does not listen to their words,
Through anger, one will go to the lower realms.

Towards those above, jealousy, rivalry and competition arise.
Towards those below, pride and arrogance when praised.
When hearing unpleasant words, anger is born.
At some point, one obtains benefit from childish actions.

When associating with the childish,
Self-praise, criticism of others,
And talk delighting in samsara -
Such non-virtues will certainly arise.

Thus, clinging to self and others
Will only lead to ruin.

Neither did they act for my benefit,
Nor will I become beneficial to them.
Therefore, one should flee far away from the childish.

When meeting, greet with joy and delight,
But do not become overly familiar.
It is best to maintain a casual, ordinary manner.

Like a bee gathering nectar from flowers,
Extract only the essence of the Dharma.
Then dwell without attachment,
As if never having seen anyone before.

If I cling to pride, thinking:
"I have many possessions and honors,
Many people are fond of me,"
Then after death, fear will arise.

Therefore, the deluded mind,
To whatever it becomes attached,
That very thing, a thousandfold,
Becomes suffering and arises as such.
Therefore, the wise do not become attached.
From attachment, fear is born.

Since these things are of a nature to be discarded,
Make yourself steadfast and realize this thoroughly.

Though many gains may come,
And fame and praise may arise,
With all these accumulations of gain and renown,
There is no certainty where one will go.

If others criticize me,
What joy is there in praise?

If others praise me,
What is there to dislike about criticism?

Even the Buddhas cannot please
All the various inclinations of sentient beings.
So what need is there to mention someone like me, so inferior?
Therefore, abandon worldly thoughts.
Disparage those who have not found their mind.
Speak ill of those who have gained.

How can joy arise
From those who are difficult to associate with by nature?

Because the childish do not experience joy
Without [pursuing] their own interests,
The Tathagatas have declared
That no childish person is a true friend.

In the forest, the wild animals and birds,
And the trees do not speak unpleasantly.

With those who bring happiness when associated with,
May I someday come to dwell together.

Dwell in a cave, in an upper temple room,
Or at the foot of a tree.

At some point, may I not look back,
And become free from attachment.

When will I dwell
Free from attachment and self-control,
In naturally vast spaces
Without claiming any land as my own?

Carrying an alms bowl and other specific items,
And wearing robes that are not needed by all.

Though this body is not hidden,
When will it dwell without fear?

Going to the charnel ground,
I will one day equalize
My body with the skulls of others,
Both being of the nature to decay.

Even this very body of mine
Will become such that
Even jackals will not approach near
Due to its stench.

Even this single body that has arisen,
With flesh and bones born together as one,
Will decay and separate apart.
What need is there to speak of other loved ones?
When born, one is born alone.
Even in death, that very essence alone dies.

If one does not take on the suffering of others,
What use is there in having friends who create obstacles?

Just as those who have entered the pure path
Hold fast to their abodes,
Likewise, those who have entered the path of existence
Fully grasp their places of rebirth.

As long as four men have not lifted
That which torments the entire world,
Until then, go to the forest.

tags:


Having neither friends nor enemies,
This body alone dwells in solitude.

Having already considered oneself as if dead,
When death comes, there is no sorrow.

Those who are seated nearby
Are free from sorrow and harm.
Thus, through this recollection of the Buddha and so forth,
No one will become distracted.

Therefore, in a delightful forest grove,
Where joy comes easily and peace abides,
Where all distractions are pacified,
I shall dwell alone in solitude.

Abandoning all other thoughts,
With single-minded focus on oneself,
Strive diligently to settle the mind in equanimity
And to tame it.

In this world and the next,
Desires give rise to misery.

Here, there is killing, binding, and cutting.
In the next life, these lead to hell and such.

For the sake of which, previously many messengers and female messengers made supplications.
For the sake of which, without hesitation, I engaged even in sinful or infamous acts.
For the sake of which, I entered into fearful situations,
And exhausted my wealth and possessions.

That which when fully embraced
Brings supreme joy,
Is nothing but a skeleton.
When there is no self-control or self,
Why, clinging to intense desire,
Do you not pass beyond sorrow?

One who at first strives diligently,
Yet when praised, looks down in modesty.

Whether seen or unseen before,
The face is now covered by a cloth.

tags:


Your face of afflictions,
Now manifested clearly before you,
Seeing it as if exposed by vultures,
Why do you now scatter in fear?

Though others may look with their eyes,
That which is completely protected,
As long as it is consumed by them,
Why do you, the miserly one, not protect it?

tags:


Seeing this heap of flesh,
If vultures and others feed on it,
Adorn the food of others
With garlands of flowers and sandalwood ornaments.

Seeing only a pile of bones,
You become frightened even though they do not move.
If they were to rise up like zombies,
How could you not be terrified?

That which clings when covered,
Why would it not desire when uncovered?

If there is no need for it,
Why embrace that which is concealed?

tags:


From a single source of food,
Both feces and saliva arise.
Yet you dislike the feces,
So why are you fond of saliva?

Though soft to touch like cotton wool,
One should not delight in pillows.
Saying "They do not leak foul odors,"
The lustful are deluded about impurity.

The foolish, evil ones full of desire,
Even when touching soft cotton,
Unable to perform sexual acts,
Become angry at it.

If you were free from attachment to impurity,
Why would you embrace in your lap
This cage of bones tied with sinews,
Smeared with the mud of flesh?

You yourself have much impurity,
Yet you constantly indulge in that very thing.
And towards other bags of impurity,
You desire them with craving for the impure.

If I say "I like this flesh,"
How can I desire to touch and look at it?

How can you desire flesh,
Which is by nature without mind?

The mind of desire
Cannot be touched or seen.
That which can be touched or seen
Is not consciousness.
What is the use of a meaningless embrace?

Not realizing the impure nature of others' bodies
Is not greatly wondrous or remarkable.

How astonishing that one does not realize
One's own inherent impurity!

Having abandoned the young lotus
Opened by the rays of the cloudless sun,
Why, with a mind attached to impurity,
Do you delight in the snare of filth?

If you do not wish to touch
A place defiled by impurities,
How then do you desire to touch
The body from which they came?

If you are not attached to impurity,
Why do you embrace in your arms
Another who was born from an impure field,
And whose seed produced that very impurity?

From impurity arises impure worms,
Even the smallest of which you do not desire.
Yet the body, which is by nature full of impurities,
You desire even though it is born from impurity.
Not only do you not criticize yourself for being impure,

The impure sack is filled with impurities,
Yet due to craving, one desires even more.

Camphor and other pleasant fragrances,
Rice porridge or even vegetable soup,
When put in the mouth, taken out, and discarded,
Even the ground becomes impure and defiled.

If you have doubts about this impurity,
Even when it is directly apparent,
Look also at other impure bodies
Discarded in charnel grounds.

Though one knows that great fear arises
When the skin is peeled away,
How is it that again and again
Delight arises towards that very thing?

The fragrance applied to the body
Is sandalwood and such, nothing else.

Why does one become attached
To others due to their scent?

Given its inherently foul nature,
Wouldn't it be better not to be attached to this?

Why add fragrant incense
To the meaningless fires of this world?
However, what has happened here to the fragrant sandalwood on the body?

Why become attached to others
Due to their fragrance?

If with long hair and nails,
Gray teeth and foul odor,
The body smeared with mud,
Is frightening when naked,
Why then do you groom yourself
As if wielding a weapon against yourself?

Through my deluded efforts,
This maddened world is thrown into turmoil.

When seeing only bare bones,
One becomes disillusioned with the charnel ground.
Yet do you delight in the village charnel ground,
Filled with moving skeletons?

Thus, that which has become impure
Cannot be obtained without a price.

By pursuing that goal to exhaustion,
One becomes harmed, as if in hell and such realms.

Since children cannot increase wealth,
What good is it when they reach adulthood?

If one spends one's life accumulating wealth,
What use is desire when old age comes?

Some evil-minded, greedy people
Become utterly exhausted by their daily labors.

Having come home, the exhausted body
Lies down like a corpse.

Some who travel far and suffer from afflictions,
Experiencing the misery of long journeys,
Though desiring to see their wives and children,
May never again behold their families' embrace.

Those who wish to help me, blinded by delusion,
Sell themselves for the sake of others.
Not attaining their goal, rendered purposeless,
They are driven by the winds of others' karma.

Some sell their own bodies,
And become powerlessly enslaved by others.

Even wives, when a child is born,
Frequently retreat to the solitude beneath trees.

Fools deceived by desire,
Saying "We wish to live, let us live!"
Enter the battlefield despite fearing loss of life.
For the sake of profit, one becomes a servant.
Some who are attached to desires even cut their own bodies.
Some are impaled on the tip of a stake.
Some are stabbed with short spears.
Some also appear to be burned.

Wealth should be understood as an endless source of trouble,
Due to the anguish of accumulating, guarding, and losing it.

Those who are distracted by attachment to wealth
Have no opportunity to be freed from the sufferings of existence.

For those filled with desire, there are many faults and drawbacks,
Yet little benefit or value.

Like oxen pulling a cart
Eating a few mouthfuls of grass along the way

tags:


Even for trivial things that could be easily obtained by animals,
This precious human rebirth of leisure and opportunity, so difficult to find,
Is destroyed by those tormented by their karma.

Desires are certain to decay and perish,
And cause one to fall into hell and other lower realms.
Since they are not great, at all times
They bring about exhausting hardships.

If with just a fraction of the effort
That one exerts for these fleeting desires,
Buddhahood itself could be achieved,
Then those attached to desires suffer more
While practicing the bodhisattva path,
Yet attain no enlightenment.

When contemplating the sufferings of hell and such,
Desires are like weapons,
Poison, fire, and precipices,
Even enemies cannot compare as examples.

Thus, having grown weary of desires,
Generate joy in solitude.

In a peaceful forest, empty of conflict and afflictions,
On a spacious stone terrace, a delightful dwelling
Cooled by sandalwood and moonlight, blessed with good fortune,
Where the silent, gentle forest breeze stirs,
One walks while contemplating how to benefit others.

In empty houses, at the foot of trees, or in caves,
Dwell wherever and for as long as you wish.
Abandon the suffering of clinging to and protecting possessions.
Act freely without concern for consequences.

Free from attachments and independent,
Unconnected to anything whatsoever,
Content and living in ease -
Even for the powerful, this state is difficult to attain.

Having contemplated the virtues of solitude
In these and other ways,
One should pacify discursive thoughts
And meditate on the mind of enlightenment.

From the very beginning, strive diligently to meditate
On the equality of self and others.

Since happiness and suffering are equal,
One should protect all beings as oneself.

Though there are many divisions like hands and so on,
They are unified as one body to be protected.
Likewise, though beings are different, their joys and sorrows
Are all equal in desiring happiness, just like oneself.

Even if my suffering
Does not harm the bodies of others,
Still, that suffering of mine
Is unbearable due to clinging to self.

Although the sufferings of others
Do not actually fall upon me,
Still, because of my attachment to self,
Their suffering is difficult for me to bear.
May I remove the suffering of others.

Just as I wish to avoid suffering,
I should strive to benefit others.
Because they are sentient beings, [treat them] like your own body.

When both myself and others
Equally desire happiness,
What difference is there between us?
Why then do I strive for happiness for myself alone?

When both myself and others
Equally do not desire suffering,
What difference is there between us?
Why then do I protect myself and not others?

If suffering does not harm oneself,
One does not need to guard against it.

If future suffering does not harm,
Why guard against it?

The thought "I have experienced that"
Is a mistaken conceptualization.

Thus, death is one thing,
And rebirth is yet another.

When any suffering arises for anyone,
If that very person protects against it,
The foot's suffering is not [protected] by the hand.
Why should one protect that?

Even if it is not logical here,
If one engages due to grasping at self,
Whatever is unreasonable regarding self and other,
Should be abandoned to the best of one's ability.

The so-called "continuum" and "assembly" are false,
Like a garland, an army, and so forth.

When suffering ceases to exist,
Who then will have power over this?

Without an owner of suffering,
All is undifferentiated.
Because it is suffering, it should be removed.
What is there to do with certainty?

Why is there no need to argue about
Reversing the suffering of all beings?
If reversed, everything is reversed.
Otherwise, I too am like a sentient being.

tags:


Why deliberately cultivate compassion
When it brings about much suffering?
If you contemplate the suffering of beings,
How can compassion not arise in abundance?

If by one suffering,
Many sufferings can be eliminated,
Then the compassionate one
Should bring about that suffering for oneself and others.

Thus, although Flower Moon Beauty knew of the king's harm,
She did not remove her own suffering,
But rather, to exhaust the suffering of many.
In this way, one who has trained their mind
Delights in pacifying others' suffering.
Like a swan entering a lotus lake,
They will even enter the Avici hell without torment.

When sentient beings are liberated,
There is an ocean of joy.
Is that itself not enough?
What should one who desires liberation do?

Therefore, even when doing good for others,
Be without pride or amazement.

Solely delighting in benefiting others,
There is no expectation of karmic fruits.

Therefore, just as one protects oneself
Even from the slightest unpleasant thing,
In the same way, one should cultivate
A mind of protection and compassion for others.

Through habituation, even though
There is no real essence in others'
Drops of semen and blood,
One comes to know them as "self."
Likewise, why not also grasp
The bodies of others as "self"?

Just as I can easily place my body elsewhere,
So too can I place it [my mind] in others without difficulty.

Knowing myself as flawed
And others as oceans of good qualities,
I should meditate on
Completely abandoning self-grasping
And embracing others.

Just as hands and such
Are considered parts of the body,
Likewise, why are beings
Not considered parts of the world?

Just as the notion of "self" arises
In this selfless body through habituation,
Likewise, why would the notion of "self" not arise
For other sentient beings through habituation?

Thus, even when benefiting others,
No sense of wonder or pride arises.

Having eaten food oneself,
One does not expect anything in return.

Therefore, just as one protects oneself
Even from the slightest unpleasant thing,
In the same way, one should cultivate
A mind of protection and compassion for all beings.

Therefore, Lord Avalokiteshvara,
Through your great compassion,
In order to dispel the fears of beings
In the cycle of existence,
You have blessed even your own name.

Do not turn back from difficulties.
Through the power of habituation,
Even that whose mere name brings fear,
When absent, becomes a source of displeasure.

Whoever wishes to quickly protect
Both oneself and others,
Should practice the supreme secret:
Exchanging self and other.

Due to attachment to this body of mine,
I fear even small sources of danger.
Who would not despise as an enemy
This body that gives rise to fear?

Those who wish to perform rituals to cure
The body's illnesses like hunger and thirst,
Kill birds, fish, and wild animals,
And lie in wait on the path.

Whoever kills even their father and mother for profit and status,
And steals from the Three Jewels,
Will burn in the Avici hell.
What wise person would desire, protect, or worship such a body?

Who here does not view [others] as enemies,
Nor looks down upon or despises [them].

If one gives, what will be left to enjoy?
Thinking only of one's own benefit is the way of demons.

If one practices, what is given?
Thinking of others' welfare is the way of the gods.

If one harms others for one's own sake,
One will suffer torment in the hells and other lower realms.

If others harm me for their own sake,
I will attain all excellent qualities.

Those who desire to elevate themselves
Will become lowly, evil, and foolish.

If one transfers that very merit to others,
One will attain the service of higher realms.

If one exploits others for one's own benefit,
One will experience [rebirth as] a servant and the like.

If one dedicates oneself for the benefit of others,
One will experience becoming a lord or master and so forth.

All the happiness that exists in the world
Arises from wishing for others' happiness.

All the sufferings of the world
Arise from desiring one's own happiness.

What need is there for many words?
Observe the difference between these two:
The childish who act for their own benefit,
And the sage who works for the benefit of others.

tags:


If one does not truly exchange
One's own happiness for others' suffering,
Buddhahood will not be attained,
And even in samsara there is no happiness.

Setting aside the next world,
Those who do not perform the work of servants,
And masters who do not give rewards,
Will not accomplish even the goals of this life.

Abandoning all perfect happiness and well-being,
Both seen and unseen, that brings about bliss.

Due to causing suffering to others,
The ignorant take on unbearable suffering themselves.

Whatever harm exists in the world,
And all the fears and sufferings that occur,
They all arise from clinging to a self.
So what use is this great demon to me?

If one does not completely let go of the self,
One cannot abandon suffering.

Just as a fire that is not extinguished
Cannot avoid burning,

Therefore, to pacify harm to myself
And to alleviate the suffering of others,
I shall give myself to others
And cherish others as I do myself.

Knowing with certainty in your mind:
"I have become subject to the power of others."

Except for the welfare of all sentient beings,
From now on, you shall think of nothing else.

It is not reasonable for the dependent senses like the eyes
To accomplish their own purpose.

Therefore, it is not right to misuse
The eyes and other senses towards that [object].

Therefore, prioritize sentient beings;
Whatever you see on your own body,
Take that and that away,
And use it to benefit others.

Having made oneself lowly and others superior,
Then having made oneself into another,
With a mind free from conceptual thought,
Meditate on jealousy, rivalry, and pride.
This is not to be revered as myself.
Thus I have not found (or realized)
This is praising others while disparaging oneself.
This self of happiness is in suffering.
I am the doer of actions.
This abides in bliss itself.

This world is considered great,
While I am known to be lowly and without virtues.

What use is there without virtues?
I myself am endowed with all virtues.

There is always someone lower than this,
And there is also always someone higher than oneself.

Moral discipline, views, and other such things
Are not under one's control due to the power of afflictions.

As much as possible, I must heal myself;
And I must also willingly accept harm.
However, this is not something I should nurture.
Why do you despise me?
What use are those qualities to me?
This is my virtuous self.

Those who dwell in the mouths of evil, vicious realms,
Who have no compassion for beings,
Yet outwardly boast of their qualities,
Wish to challenge the wise.

Looking at those equal to myself,
For the sake of elevating oneself above them,
My own gain and honors
I will surely secure even through dispute.

May my own qualities be clear to all the world,
Yet may no one hear of this one's qualities.
One should conceal one's own faults.
I am not the one to be worshipped here.
Today, I have obtained an excellent attainment.
I will not be honored for this.

For a long time, I have delightedly observed
Those who commit evil deeds.

Make all beings laugh and smile,
And praise each other mutually.

These afflictions are said to compete
Together with the self.

tags:


Are these equal in hearing and wisdom?
Or are they equal in form, lineage, and wealth?

Thus, having proclaimed to all,
Upon hearing my virtuous qualities,
With hairs raised and joy arising,
They fully experience happiness and bliss.

Even if there is gain to be found here,
If it is my work to be done,
Having given just enough for sustenance,
I should take it through my own strength.
This is to be experienced as bliss.
May I always be connected with harm to my ego/self.

This has harmed me in hundreds of ways
Throughout all my cycles of rebirth.

O mind, though countless eons have passed
While you've desired to accomplish your own aims,
Through such great exertion and toil,
You have achieved nothing but suffering.

Thus, with certainty,
Engage yourself fully
In the welfare of others.

The words of the Sage are infallible;
Their virtues will be seen later.

If you had performed these actions in the past,
It would not be possible for you to be in this situation,
Other than in the perfect bliss of Buddhahood.

Therefore, just as you have developed a sense of "I" and "mine"
Towards this drop of semen and blood of others,
In the same way, cultivate that attitude
Towards all other beings as well.

After deeply contemplating others,
Whatever appears in your own body,
Having seized that very thing,
Use it to benefit others.

I am happy while others are not,
I am high while others are low,
I am beneficial while others are not -
Why should I not be envious of myself?
May I be separated from happiness.
May the suffering of others be transferred to me.

At all times, examine your own faults,
Asking yourself, "What am I doing?"

Even when others commit faults,
Transform them into your own shortcomings.

Though my faults may be small,
They spread widely among many beings.

By excessively praising the fame of others,
One's own fame is overshadowed.

Like the lowest of servants,
I shall be employed for all purposes.
This is the nature of faults/defects.
Do not praise sudden or temporary virtues.

By whatever means possible,
Let no one know of these virtues;
Keep them hidden in this way.

tags:


In short, whatever harm you have done to others
For your own benefit,
May that harm, for the sake of sentient beings,
Fall upon myself instead.

In this way, one should not generate forceful strength
That leads to becoming stiff-necked and rigid.

Like a new bride,
Restrained by modesty and fear.
Do that That is to be done
Thus one should abide.
Thus, you should not do this.
Thus, this is to be mastered.
If one goes beyond that, they should be disciplined.

However, even if instructed in this way,
If you, mind, do not act accordingly,
Since all faults rely on you,
You alone must be disciplined.

The time in the past when you lost me
Was different from now;
I have seen [this].
Where are you going now?
May all your pride be conquered.

Abandon the thought that there is still
Something left to do for your own sake.
I will sell you to others.
Do not be discouraged; offer yogurt and meat.

If you become careless and do not give
To sentient beings,
You will certainly give yourself
To the guardians of hell.

Thus, look with hope.
I have long suffered from giving.

I recall all conflicts,
While you destroy thoughts of self-interest.

If I desire happiness,
I should not please myself.

If I wish to protect myself,
I should always protect others.

The more one indulges and pampers this body,
The more it becomes delicate and vulnerable.
The more one caters to its every whim,
The more it falls prey to sensitivity and weakness.

Thus, even for one who has fallen in this way,
All the desires of this earthly realm
Cannot be fully satisfied.
Who then can fulfill such desires?

Powerless desires lead to afflictions,
And deterioration of intention also arises.

One who is independent of all,
Their abundance is inexhaustible.

Therefore, one should not make room for bodily desires,
As they only increase and multiply.

That which does not cling to what is pleasing
Is truly an excellent thing.

In the end, reduced to ashes,
Motionless, to be moved by others,
This impure form, unbearable to behold,
Why do we cling to it as self?
It is better to live or even to die.
What use is this machine (or mechanism) to me?

What difference is there between this and a donkey?
Alas! It does not remove pride.

By heeding the demands of the body,
We needlessly accumulate suffering.
Attachment and anger that follow -
What use are they for this body, which is like a piece of wood?

Whether I preserve this [body] like this,
Or it is eaten by vultures and such,
If there is no attachment or hatred,
Why should one become attached to it?

Whoever becomes angry when criticized,
And whoever becomes pleased when praised,
If they lack understanding of their true nature,
For whom have I exerted my efforts?

If one desires this body,
And claims to be a friend to the self,
Since all desire their own bodies,
Why then not be fond of all?

Therefore, without attachment,
I shall give up my body for the benefit of beings.

Therefore, although there are many faults in this,
One should grasp it as if performing a ritual action.
Therefore, be content with childlike conduct.
I follow in the footsteps of the wise.

Having mindfully recalled words of caution,
One should dispel sleep and drowsiness.

Like the great compassionate bodhisattvas,
One should cultivate the patience of insight.

If I do not strive day and night,
When will my suffering come to an end?

Therefore, in order to remove obscurations,
Turning the mind away from mistaken paths,
I shall constantly and steadily
Place myself in meditative equipoise on the perfect object.

From "Engaging in the Conduct of Bodhisattvas":
This is the eighth chapter, called "Teaching on Meditation."

All these branches (or aspects)
Were taught by the Sage for the sake of wisdom.

Therefore, those who wish to pacify sufferings
Should cultivate wisdom.

tags:


Conventional and ultimate -
These are accepted as the two truths.
Ultimate reality is not an object of conceptual thought.
Mind is said to be conventional truth.
In this, one sees the two aspects of the world.
Yogis and ordinary people.

As for ordinary worldly people,
They are harmed by the world of yogic practitioners.

Even among yogis, those of higher understanding
Refute those below them.

Both are like desire;
Because the fruit is not examined,
Worldly people see things directly.

Though one may conceptualize it as truly existent,
It is not like an illusion here.
Thus, the yogi and the worldly person argue.

Even the direct perception of form and so forth
Is due to convention, not by valid cognition.

That which is impure and so forth,
Is falsely renowned as pure and so on.

For the sake of guiding worldly beings,
The Protector taught these things as real,
Yet they are not truly momentary.

If one objects that this contradicts conventional reality,
For the yogi, conventional reality is without fault.
In relation to the world, they see the true nature of things.

Elsewhere, women are considered impure.
By such thinking, the world becomes harmful.

tags:


From illusory actions, how can merit
Be as real as it seems?
If sentient beings are like illusions,
How can they be reborn after death?

As long as the conditions are gathered,
For that long, even illusions will arise.

How can sentient beings truly exist,
Merely by virtue of long duration?

Since an illusory person who is killed and so forth
Has no mind, there is no sin.

For one who possesses an illusory mind,
Both merit and sin arise.

Because mantras and such have no power,
The illusory mind does not arise.

From various conditions arise
These diverse illusions.

There is nowhere that a single cause
Can produce all effects.

If ultimate truth is nirvana,
And samsara is conventional truth,
Then even Buddhas would be in samsara.
So what use is the practice of enlightenment?

If the stream of conditions is unbroken,
Even illusions will not cease to appear.

Since the continuum of conditions is severed,
Even conventionally, [phenomena] do not arise.

When there is no delusion,
By what could illusion be perceived?

When you yourself have no illusion,
At that time, what is there to perceive?

If others exist in that very essence,
That aspect is the mind itself.

When the mind itself is an illusion,
Then what is seen, and by whom?

Even the protector of the world has said,
"Mind cannot see mind."

Just as a sword's blade does not cut itself,
Likewise, the mind [does not harm itself].

Just as a lamp illuminates
Its own nature perfectly,
The lamp need not be illuminated,
For it is not obscured by darkness.

Like blue crystal is blue in itself,
It does not depend on anything else.

Likewise, some see others as
Both dependent and independent.

That which is blue is not blueness itself.
The self does not create itself.

When one says "The lamp illuminates,"
It is known and expressed through awareness.
But who knows and declares that
"The mind itself is luminous"?

When something is not seen by anyone,
Whether clear or unclear,
It is like the graceful gait of a barren woman's daughter.
To speak of it is meaningless.

If self-awareness does not exist,
How can consciousness be remembered?

When experiencing others' [suffering],
Through connection, one remembers,
Like the poison of a rat.

When other conditions are present,
For the sake of seeing, one's own nature becomes clear.
From the composition of accomplished eye medicine,
Seeing a vase does not make the eye medicine itself.

Whatever is seen, heard, or known,
Is not to be negated here.

Here, what has become the cause of suffering
Is to be reversed: the conception of truth.

The mind is nothing other than illusion,
Yet it is not other and is impermanent.
How then, in reality, can it not be other?
If it is not other, then it does not exist as a real entity.

Just as an illusion is not real,
So too the mind that perceives it.

If samsara had a real basis,
It would become like space elsewhere.

Since the non-existent depends on the existent,
How can it become endowed with action?

Your mind, without companions,
Becomes solitary and alone.

When the mind is free from grasping,
At that time, all is Thus Gone (Tathagata).

Even so, what benefit is there
In conceiving of mind-only?

Even if one knows [all phenomena] to be like an illusion,
How can the afflictions be reversed?

At the time when even the illusionist himself
Becomes attached to the illusory woman he has created.

That which does this is known as
Not abandoning afflictive emotions and habitual tendencies.
Therefore, when seeing that,
The subtle imprints of emptiness

By familiarizing oneself with the imprints of emptiness,
One will abandon the imprints of concrete things.

Through familiarizing oneself with "nothing exists",
Even that [concept] will later be abandoned.

When something is said not to exist,
And the object of investigation is not perceived,
At that time, how can non-existence, devoid of basis,
Remain before the mind?

When neither existence nor non-existence
Remain before the mind,
At that time, with no other appearances,
Without a focal point, there is perfect peace.

Like a wish-fulfilling jewel or a wish-granting tree
That completely satisfies all desires,
So too, by the power of the aspirations of those to be tamed,
The Victor's form appears.

For example, like a garuda bird
That has completed building a chorten and then passed away

Even though much time has passed since then,
It still pacifies poisons and the like.

In accordance with the conduct of enlightenment,
Even the victory stupa that was accomplished,
Though the bodhisattva has passed beyond sorrow,
Still performs all beneficial deeds.

How can there be any fruit (result)
From making offerings to that which has no mind?

Because whether abiding or passed into nirvana,
It is explained to be equivalent.

Whether conventionally or ultimately,
It is suitable; this result comes from scripture.

For example, just as the true Buddha
Is endowed with the fruit (of enlightenment),

By seeing the truth, one becomes liberated.
What use is there in seeing emptiness?

For it is stated in scripture that without this path,
There is no enlightenment.

If the Great Vehicle is not established,
How then is your scripture established?
Because this is established for both.
First, this is not established for you.

Whatever causes one to have faith in that,
The same applies to the Mahayana as well.

If the other two are true because they are desired,
Then the Vedas and such would also become true.

If it is said that the Mahayana is controversial,
Then regarding scripture, even the non-Buddhists,
And regarding other scriptures, both our own and others,
Are controversial, therefore they should be abandoned.

If the foundation of the teachings is monkhood itself,
Then even monkhood remains difficult to maintain.

For those whose minds have attachments,
Even attaining nirvana is difficult.

If liberation comes from abandoning afflictions,
One would become liberated immediately upon doing so.

Though free from afflictions, in them
The power of karma is seen.

For a moment, if one is certain that
There is no craving as the immediate cause,
Even though that craving is not afflicted,
Why would it not exist, just like ignorance?
Due to the condition of feeling, there is craving.
Those sensations also exist.

tags:


The mind with focus and attachment
Will come to dwell on certain things.

The mind devoid of emptiness
Will cease and be reborn again.
Like the meditative absorption of non-perception
Therefore, one should meditate on emptiness.

tags:


If you wish to claim that any speech that enters into the sutras
Was spoken by the Buddha,
Then are not most of your Mahayana texts
Equivalent to sutras as well?

If by excluding one [teaching],
All [teachings] become flawed,
Why then, by the same logic, does not
A single [teaching] make all [the Buddha's words] true?

That speech which even great Mahakashyapa
And others could not fathom,
You have not realized.
Who can claim it is not to be grasped?

For the sake of those suffering from delusion,
Free from the extremes of attachment and fear,
Abiding in samsara yet attaining accomplishment -
This is the fruit of emptiness.
Thus, it is not appropriate to refute or criticize the aspect of emptiness.

Therefore, without doubt,
One should meditate on emptiness.

Emptiness is the antidote to the darkness
Of afflictive emotions and cognitive obscurations.

Desiring to swiftly become omniscient,
How can one not meditate on that?

If fear arises from that which produces suffering,
How can one be afraid of emptiness,
Which pacifies all suffering?

If there were a self, one would fear everything.
But since there is no self whatsoever,
Who is there to be afraid?
Teeth, hair, and nails are not the self.
I am not bones and blood.
Not mucus
It is neither lymph nor pus.
I am neither marrow nor sweat.
The lungs and liver are also not the self.
The other internal organs are also not the self.
I am not feces and urine.
Flesh and skin are not the self.
Neither heat nor wind are the self.
Not self-originated/Not self-existent
In all aspects, the six consciousnesses are also not the self.

If sound cognition were permanent,
One would perceive sound at all times.
If there is nothing to be known, what is there to understand?
By what is consciousness expressed?

If ignorance were knowledge,
Even wood would become conscious.

Therefore, it is certain that without an object of knowledge nearby,
There can be no cognition (or consciousness).

If one understands form through that very [wisdom],
Then why would hearing also not [be understood]?

If sound is not near,
Then there is also no cognition of it.

How can that which is of the nature of sound perception
Become a perceiver of form?
One is conceptualized as father and son.

It is not truly real. Thus, courage, energy, and
darkness are neither child nor father.

That which possesses sound-grasping
Is not seen as having inherent nature.

Like an actor who takes on different roles,
When one sees the true nature, it is not permanent.

If that very essence were different,
Then that single one would be a new single one that did not exist before.

If the other method is not true,
Then state its own inherent nature.

If [you say] it is mere consciousness,
Then it follows that all beings would be one.

Thoughts and non-thoughts alike
Become one, for they equally exist.

When distinctions are mistaken,
What then is the basis for similarity?

That which is without mind is also not the self,
Because of its very mindlessness, like a vase and so forth.

However, because it possesses mind,
If one knows, it follows that not knowing would be destroyed.

If there is no change in myself,
What can thinking accomplish for it?

In this way, one who is free from conceptual thought and activity
Becomes one with the nature of space itself.

If there is no self,
Then the connection between actions and their results is not logical.

When actions are done and then cease,
Who do those actions belong to, one may ask?
The act, its result, and the basis are distinct,
And there is no self performing them.
Since both father and son have established this,
Is this debate here not pointless?

Seeing cause and effect together
Is not possible in this existence.

Depending on a single continuum,
It is taught that there is an agent and an experiencer.

The mind of the past and future
Is not the self, for it does not exist.

However, if the born mind is the self,
When that ceases, there is no self.

For example, when a plantain tree
Is divided into parts, nothing remains.
Likewise, when analyzed through investigation,
The self is found to be not truly existent.

If sentient beings do not exist,
To whom should compassion be shown?
It is that which is conceived by delusion,
Accepted for the sake of attaining the result.
Sentient beings are without inherent existence.
True, yet desire arises from ignorance.

In order to pacify suffering,
Do not turn away from the delusion of results.

The pride that is the cause of suffering
Increases due to delusion about the self.

If there is no way to reverse this,
Meditation on selflessness is supreme.
The body is not the feet or calves.
Neither thighs nor waist are the self.
The front and back are also not the body.
Neither the chest nor the shoulders are the body.
The ribs, sides, and hands are also not the body.
The armpit and shoulder are also not the body.
The internal organs are also not that.

If the head and neck are not the body,
Then what indeed is the body here?

If this entire body
Were to reside in just one part,
The parts would dwell within parts,
But where then would the self reside?

If the self resided in all parts of the body,
Such as the hands and so forth,
Then there would be as many selves
As there are parts of the body.

If there is no body inside or outside,
How can there be a body in hands and other parts?

If there is nothing other than parts like hands,
How can that [whole] exist?

Therefore, due to ignorance,
The notion of a body arises
In relation to the bodiless hands and other parts.

Due to the distinctive arrangement of its shape,
[It is] like the mind's perception of a scarecrow.

As long as the collection of conditions persists,
The body appears like a person.
Likewise, as long as there are hands and such,
For that duration, the body appears there.

Likewise, since it is a collection of fingers,
What indeed could the hand be?

tags:


Moreover, since it is a collection of parts,
The parts too can be divided into their components.
Those components can be further divided into particles.

Even that particle, by division of its parts,
And the division of parts being without portions,
Is like space; therefore, even particles do not exist.

Thus, who among the wise would be attached
To forms that are like a dream?

When there is no body in this way,
At that time, who is born and who is female?

If suffering truly exists,
Why does it not harm supreme joy?

If in happiness, why not rejoice
In sorrow, pain, and suffering too?

If one does not experience that which
Is overpowered by the mighty,
Then who is it that has the experience?
How is that feeling?

Even the subtlest suffering exists.
Is this not to remove the gross [suffering]?

If it is said that this is merely a different kind of pleasure,
Then that too is subtle, and if it is that,
If due to arising adverse conditions,
Suffering does not arise,
Is it not established that
This is just clinging to the concept of feeling?

Therefore, as an antidote to this,
One should meditate on this discerning wisdom.

The food of meditation yogis
Arises from the field of conceptual analysis.

If there is a mediator between the senses and their objects,
Where would they actually meet?
Even without intermediaries, it is still one.
Whatever meets with whatever.
There is no entering into atoms within atoms.
That is the state of equality without refuge.
Not entering, yet without mixing.
For that which is unmixed, there is no meeting.

How can there be a "meeting"
For that which has no parts?

If you see [something] without meeting or parts,
Then teach [about it].

For consciousness without a body,
Contact is indeed not possible.

The assembly also lacks inherent existence,
As previously analyzed in detail.

tags:


If contact does not exist in that way,
From where would feeling arise?
For what purpose is this weariness?
Who harms whom?

When there is no perceiver,
And perception also does not exist,
At that time, seeing this state,
Why would craving not cease?

Seeing or touching,
Like a dream or illusion in nature,
Because they arise together with mind,
That sensation does not truly see.

By being born in the past and future,
One becomes mindful.
It is not experienced.

It is not experienced by oneself,
Nor is it experienced by others.
There is no feeling whatsoever.
Therefore, that is not feeling itself.

Thus, to this selfless assembly,
Why should this cause harm?
The mind does not abide in the senses.
Not in form and so forth
Neither in between.
Not even the mind within
It is not external.
It is not to be found elsewhere.

tags:


That which is not the body, not elsewhere,
Not mixed, nor separate anywhere,
That is nothing at all; therefore,
The nature of beings is nirvana.

If knowledge existed prior to the object of knowledge,
What would it be focused on in order to arise?

When knowledge and the object of knowledge are simultaneous,
Upon what does that [knowledge] arise and focus?

However, if the object of knowledge exists later,
Then from what does the consciousness arise at that time?

Thus, the arising of all phenomena
Cannot be fully comprehended.

If conventional reality does not exist in this way,
How can there be two truths for it?

Moreover, from the perspective of conventional truth,
How could sentient beings pass beyond sorrow?
This is the conceptual thought of others' minds.
That is not one's own conventional truth.
Later, if that is certain, then that exists.
If not, then conventional reality itself would not exist.

The conceptualizer and that which is conceptualized
Are mutually dependent upon each other.

Based on what is known,
All analysis is expressed.

When one analyzes with discerning wisdom,
That very discernment itself
Is also subject to analysis.
Thus, there is no end to discernment.

When thoroughly analyzing the object of analysis,
There is no basis for analytical wisdom.
Since there is no basis, it does not arise.
That is also called passing beyond sorrow.
According to whom are these two true?
That itself remains extremely difficult.

If results are achieved through the power of knowledge,
What need is there to rely on mere existence of knowledge?

However, knowledge arises from the knowable.
What is the basis for the existence of the knowable?

If they exist in mutual dependence,
Both will become non-existent.

If there is no father without a son,
From where did the son himself arise?

Without a child, there is no father;
Likewise, neither of these two exist inherently.

The sprout grows from the seed,
And is understood through that very seed itself.

By the knowledge born from the knowable,
Why is its existence not understood?

If by knowledge other than the sprout,
One realizes the existence of the seed,
Then by what means does one realize
The very existence of the knowledge that realizes that object?

For now, through direct perception of the world,
All causes are seen.

The distinctions of lotus stems and such
Are produced by the distinctions of causes.

If one asks, "By what cause is this distinction made?"
It is by the very distinction of causes that came before.

Why can a cause produce an effect?
It is due to the power of the previous cause itself.

If the Lord (Ishvara) is the cause of beings,
For now, please state what this Lord is.
If one asks about the elements, it is indeed so.
Why exhaust oneself even for mere names?

However, [it is] many like earth and so forth,
Impermanent, unmoving, not divine,
To be trodden upon, and impure.
Therefore, it is not the nature of the Lord.
Because the sovereign lord is neither sky nor immovable.
Because the self has already been refuted before.

For the one who acts without thought,
What use is there in speaking without thought?
What is it that generates desire?

Am I not eternal, like that [Brahman],
And also like earth and the other elements,
As well as the essence of the Lord [Ishvara]?

Consciousness arises from objects of knowledge,
And beginningless pleasure and pain arise from karma.
What is produced by that? Tell me.

If there is no beginning to causes,
How could there be a beginning to effects?

Why does one not always act?
Because that does not depend on others.

If there is nothing else that is not done by that,
Then upon what could this depend?
If one examines closely, it is the collection of causes and conditions that is the origin, not some supreme being.

Without accumulation, one has no power to be born;
Yet without that [birth], one has no power to accumulate.

If the Lord acts against his own will,
He would fall under the power of others.
Even if one desires, one becomes dependent on desire.
Even if one does so, how could there be a supreme lord?

Those who assert that particles are permanent
Have already been refuted earlier.

The Samkhya philosophers assert that the principal (pradhana),
Which is permanent, is the cause of living beings.

Courage, energy, and darkness -
These qualities existing in balance
Are proclaimed to be the principal elements.
It is said that beings are unequal.

It is not logical for one thing to have three inherent natures.
Therefore, that [threefold nature] does not exist.

Likewise, there are no qualities [in inherent existence].
This is also due to the three individual [reasons].

Without virtuous qualities, even sound and the like
Become extremely distant from true existence.

In mindless things like clothes and such,
There cannot possibly exist pleasure and the like.

Since phenomena have the nature of their causes,
Have not all phenomena already been thoroughly examined?

Your cause is also happiness and such.
From that, cloth and so forth do not arise.
From cloth and such arise pleasure and the like.
Because that does not exist, there is no happiness and so forth.

Happiness and such are never
Observed to be permanent.

If happiness and other [experiences] are clearly existent,
Why are they not grasped as experiences?

If that very thing becomes subtle,
How can it be both coarse and fine?

Having abandoned the coarse and become subtle,
Those subtle and coarse [phenomena] are impermanent.

In the same way, why not accept
That all phenomena are impermanent?

If coarseness is nothing other than bliss,
Then bliss itself is clear and impermanent.

If you claim that nothing arises
Because there is no non-existence,
Then even though you do not accept it,
The fact remains that the non-manifest arises.

If the effect exists within the cause,
Then eating food would be eating excrement.

tags:


With the price of cloth, buy cotton seeds and distribute them.

If the deluded world does not see it,
That very reality is established by those who know.
Since that knowledge exists even in the world,
Why is it not seen?

If the world itself is not a valid cognition,
Even seeing something clearly is not necessarily true.

If the valid cognition is not valid,
Would not its object of knowledge become false?

Therefore, in that very state,
Meditation on emptiness
Would thus become invalid.

Without touching the conceptualized entities,
One does not grasp their non-existence.

Therefore, whatever is a false entity,
Its non-existence is clearly false as well.

Therefore, in a dream where a child dies,
The thought "he is gone"
Is an obstacle to the conception
That he exists. Yet that too is false.

Therefore, upon such analysis,
Nothing exists without a cause.

Neither in individual [causes] nor in combined conditions
Is there an abiding place [for phenomena].
It does not come from elsewhere.
Not abiding
Do not go.

What the deluded perceive as real,
How is it different from an illusion?

That which is created by illusion,
And that which is produced by causes,
From where does it come,
And where does it go? Investigate this.

That which appears when something is near,
But does not exist when that thing is absent,
Is like a reflected image - artificial.
How can such a thing possess true reality?

For that which already exists,
What need is there for a cause?

However, if that does not exist,
What purpose does the cause serve?

Even with a hundred billion causes,
That which does not exist cannot be transformed.
How is that state in reality?
What else is there that truly changes?

If non-existence is impossible,
When would things ever come into existence?

Without things coming into existence,
Non-existence cannot be separated from them.

If not separated from non-existence,
The possibility of existence cannot occur.

Things do not become non-existent,
For that would lead to the fallacy of two natures.

Thus, there is no cessation,
Nor is there any real existence.
Therefore, all these beings
Are eternally unborn and unceased.
Sentient beings are like a dream.
When thoroughly examined, [all phenomena are] like a plantain tree.

There is no difference, in reality,
Between nirvana and non-nirvana.
Thus, in all empty phenomena, what is there to gain?
What is there to lose?

What is there to be gained by performing rituals,
Or what is there to be lost by complete disregard?
From where does happiness and suffering arise?
What is there to dislike?
What is there to be happy about?

If one searches within that very [reality],
What is it that craves and what is craved?

Upon examination, in this world of the living,
Who among us will not die here?
Whatever will arise has already arisen.
Who truly are our relatives and friends?

Like all things are similar to space,
May I fully grasp them as such.

Those who desire happiness for themselves,
Through causes of conflict and excitement,
Become greatly agitated and joyful.

Through sorrow, effort, and strife;
Through mutual cutting and piercing;
By great sins one lives with difficulty.

Again and again one is born in happy realms,
Experiencing many pleasures repeatedly.
But after death, one falls into the lower realms,
Enduring long-lasting, unbearable sufferings.
In the cycle of existence, there are many precipices.
That is not exactly like this.

Moreover, due to their mutual contradiction,
Such ultimate reality does not exist in samsara.

Moreover, this boundless ocean of suffering,
Incomparable and unbearable,
Is beyond all limits.
There, in that way, being of little strength,
There, life itself is short indeed.

Even there, life swiftly passes without meaning,
Through the futile efforts of the living and healthy,
The weariness of hunger and thirst,
Sleep and harm, and likewise,
Associating pointlessly with the childish.
Wisdom is extremely difficult to attain.

Moreover, for one accustomed to distraction,
How can there be a method to reverse it?

Moreover, in order to cause a fall into the great lower realms,
The demon exerts great effort.
There are many wrong paths there.
Even doubt is difficult to overcome.
Once again, this precious human life is difficult to obtain.
It is extremely difficult to encounter a Buddha.
The river of afflictions is difficult to abandon.
Alas! Suffering will continue.

Though suffering greatly,
Those who do not see their own misery,
These beings dwelling in rivers of suffering -
Alas! They are worthy of lamentation.

For example, someone who repeatedly bathes,
Then repeatedly enters into fire,
Thus, although dwelling in extreme suffering,
Still imagines themselves to be in bliss.

Thus, living as if there were no old age and death,
Indulging in worldly activities,
Having killed from the very beginning,
One will fall into the unbearable lower realms.

When will I become one who pacifies
The suffering of those tormented by the fires of misery,
With a rain of happiness gathered from my own merit,
Well-born from the clouds of virtue?

At some point, in a way free from conceptual focus,
Respectfully accumulate the collection of merit.

To those who would be ruined by conceptualization,
Emptiness is taught.

From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas":
This is the ninth chapter, on the Perfection of Wisdom.

By the virtue of my composing this treatise
On entering the conduct of enlightenment,
May all beings enter into
The conduct of enlightenment.

tags:


In all directions, may those beings
Whose bodies and minds suffer illness,
Through my merit,
Obtain an ocean of happiness and joy.

For as long as they remain in samsara,
May they never fall from happiness.
May all beings attain the unceasing bliss of the bodhisattvas.

May all sentient beings in the various hells
That exist throughout the world systems
Be filled with joy through the bliss of Sukhavati (the Pure Land of Great Bliss).
May those suffering from cold obtain warmth.

tags:


From the great cloud of the bodhisattva,
May the endless rivers that emerge
Cool those tormented by heat.

Even the forest of sword-like leaves,
May it become a dense sandalwood grove.

May even the thorn trees of the Shalmali forest
Be transformed into wish-fulfilling trees.
May it be adorned by the melodious calls of blue rollers, ruddy shelducks, geese, and other birds with sweet voices.

May the regions of hell become delightful
Through lotus-filled lakes of fragrant perfume.
Those heaps of ashes transformed into piles of precious jewels.
May the ground become a smooth surface of burnt earth and crystal.

May the mountains of condensed destruction
Become immeasurable palaces filled with Buddhas.

tags:


From now on, may the rain of weapons, burning coals, and embers
Transform into a shower of flowers.

May those who attack each other with weapons
From now on throw flowers at each other in play instead.

Those sunk in a pit of fire without a river,
Their flesh decayed, bones white as jasmine flowers.
By the power of my virtue, may they attain divine bodies,
And dwell with goddesses where gentle streams flow.

Why are the fearsome messengers of death, crows, and vultures here now terrified?
Wondering whose great power this is that dispels all darkness and brings joy and bliss,
Looking upward, they see Vajrapani blazing in the midst of the sky.
May we, freed from sins by the force of great joy, accompany him together.

May a rain of flowers mixed with scented water fall,
Extinguishing the blazing embers of hell before their eyes.
Suddenly filled with joy, they wonder what this could be,
And may those in the hell realms behold Avalokiteshvara.
Friends, abandon fear and come here quickly!

Regarding the child:
By whose power all suffering is dispelled and the force of joy arrives,
Who completely protects all beings and gives rise to bodhicitta and compassion,
What has come that makes the radiant youth with topknot fearless?

The hundred deities' crowns worship your lotus feet,
Your compassionate, moist eyes rain down showers of many flowers upon your head.
Behold this: a thousand lovely goddesses in multi-storied palaces singing hymns of praise.
Having seen such a Manjushri, may the clamor of hell beings now be silenced.

Thus, by my virtuous roots, may all beings see Samantabhadra and other
Bodhisattvas, free from obscurations, like cooling pleasant-scented rain
falling from cloudless skies. And upon seeing this, may even the beings in hell
realms become truly joyful.

tags:

May all animals be free from the fear of being eaten by one another.

Like the people of Uttarakuru,
May all hungry ghosts become happy.

tags:


May the stream of milk flowing from the hand
Of noble Avalokiteshvara
Satisfy the hungry ghosts,
And may they be forever cooled by bathing in it.

May the blind see,
And may the deaf always hear sounds.

Like the illusory manifestation of a goddess,
May the pregnant woman give birth without harm.

May the naked obtain clothes,
May the hungry obtain food,
May the thirsty obtain water,
And may they receive delicious drinks.
May the poor obtain wealth.
May those who are sorrowful and weary attain joy.

May those who are discouraged be uplifted,
And may they attain perfect stability.

May all sentient beings who are ill
Be swiftly freed from their sickness.

May all the illnesses of beings
Be completely and forever eliminated.
May those who are afraid become fearless.
Those who are bound will become liberated.
The powerless become powerful.
May our minds be gentle and flexible towards one another.

May all beings in all directions
Be happy and at ease.

May that which you set out to accomplish
Be achieved effortlessly, without struggle.

tags:


May those who board boats and ships
Have their wishes fulfilled in their minds.
After safely reaching the shore,
May they rejoice together with their loved ones.

May those who have strayed onto sorrowful paths and wander lost
Meet with good companions along the way,
And travel on easily and tirelessly without fear
Of thieves, tigers, or other dangers.

In desolate places without paths, where it is frightening,
For children, the elderly, and those without protection,
For those who are asleep, intoxicated, or deeply inebriated,
May the deities provide protection.

May I be free from all weariness and exhaustion,
Endowed with faith, wisdom, and compassion,
Blessed with abundant food and excellent conduct,
And always remember my past lives.

May all things be like the treasury of space,
An inexhaustible source of enjoyment.
May we act freely, without conflict or harm.

May all beings of little splendor
Become beings of great splendor.

May those who practice austerities and have ugly forms
Become endowed with excellent and perfect forms.

May all the women in the world
Transform into men.

May the lowly attain high status,
And may pride also be destroyed.

By this merit of mine,
May all sentient beings without exception
Abandon all negativities,
And always perform virtuous actions.
Not separating from the mind of enlightenment.
Dedicated to the practice of enlightenment.
May I be fully embraced by all the Buddhas.
May [we] abandon all demonic actions.

tags as requested:

May all those sentient beings
Have immeasurably long lives.
May you always live in happiness and well-being.
May even the sound of death not be heard.

tags:


May all directions be filled
With gardens of wish-fulfilling trees,
Resounding with the teachings of the Dharma
From Buddhas and their spiritual heirs.

tags:


Everywhere the ground is pure,
Free from pebbles and the like.
Smooth as the palm of a hand,
It becomes the nature of soft lapis lazuli.

In all the mandalas of the assembly,
May many bodhisattvas reside,
Adorning the surface of the earth
With their own excellent qualities.

May all beings continuously hear the sound of Dharma
From birds, trees, and all rays of light,
And even from the sky itself,
Without interruption.
May they always encounter Buddhas and the children of Buddhas.

With limitless clouds of offerings,
May I make offerings to the gurus of all beings.
The gods also bring rain in due season.
May the crops be abundant.
May the king act in accordance with the Dharma.
May the world also flourish.

May medicines be endowed with potency,
And may the recitation of secret mantras be accomplished.

May dakinis, rakshasas, and others
Be endowed with minds of compassion.
May no sentient being suffer.
One does not become fearful or contemptuous.
May no one become unhappy.
May the temples be adorned with study and recitation, and may they remain in excellent condition.

May the Sangha always be in harmony,
And may the purposes of the Sangha be accomplished.

May monks who desire training
Also attain solitude.

Having abandoned all distractions,
May the mind become workable through meditation.
May the nuns be prosperous and endowed with attainments.
May [we/I] abandon conflict and harmful actions.

Likewise, may all those who have renounced worldly life
Be free from any decline in their moral discipline.

Having become disillusioned with immoral conduct,
May I always exhaust negative karma.

Having attained favorable rebirths as well,
May my spiritual discipline not deteriorate even there.

May the wise be respected,
And may they also obtain alms.

May the mind be completely purified,
And may [this teaching] become renowned in all directions.
May [they] not experience the suffering of the lower realms.

Without enduring hardships,
May they swiftly attain Buddhahood
With bodies surpassing even the gods.

May all sentient beings repeatedly
Make offerings to all the Buddhas.

tags:


May the immeasurable bliss of the Buddha
Always bring happiness and well-being.

May the bodhisattvas accomplish their intention
To benefit all beings.

tags:


May whatever the Protector has intended
Be fulfilled for all sentient beings.
Likewise, may all the solitary realizers (pratyekabuddhas) and hearers (shravakas) be happy.

Through the kindness of Manjushri,
Until I attain the first ground of supreme joy,
May I always remember my past lives,
And may I attain ordination as a monk.

May I, even through my food and drink,
Be endowed with spiritual experience and sustain my life.

In all lifetimes, may I attain
Perfect abundance in solitary places.

tags:


When I wish to see or
Have even a small question,
May I behold the protector Manjushri himself
Without any obstacles.

tags:


For the benefit of all sentient beings
Pervading the limits of space in the ten directions,
Just as Manjushri performs his activities,
May my conduct also be like that.

As long as space endures,
And as long as living beings remain,
Until then may I too abide,
To dispel the misery of the world.

Whatever sufferings sentient beings may have,
May all of those ripen upon me.

May the Sangha of Bodhisattvas
Bring happiness to all beings.

The sole medicine for the suffering of beings,
The source from which all happiness arises,
May the Dharma, along with its discovery, veneration,
And practice, long endure.

I bow down to Manjushri,
By whose kindness virtuous thoughts arise.

I prostrate to the virtuous spiritual friend,
By whose kindness I have flourished.
From "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas," this is the tenth chapter called "Dedication."
The Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life, composed by Master Shantideva, is complete.
The Indian abbot Sarvajñadeva and the great translator Bande Paltseg revised and finalized [this text] based on the Kashmiri version.
